story.title: Delean-Botkin resigns from Talbot Board of Education
story.author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
story.content:
Delean-Botkin resigns from Talbot Board of Education

 August 4, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 472
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Susan Delean-Botkin has stepped down from the Talbot County Board of Education since being appointed an Oxford Commissioner.In an interview, Delean-Botkin said she made the decision to leave the school board due to personal reasons and her new role in Oxford's local government.Delean-Botkin said she already misses being on the Board of Education "tremendously." "School board was a fabulous experience," she said. "Interacting with really great administrators, wonderful teachers, fantastic students, working with the board members, all of whom were really top quality people to work with." Delean-Botkin was sworn into the Talbot County Board of Education District 5 seat in January 2017. She was elected president of the board in December 2020 and held the role through 2022.Moving forward, Delean-Botkin said she hopes the Board of Education continues to maintain the county's high graduation rate and low dropout rate, expand its Career and Technical Education completer courses and implement the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, a statewide plan to increase public education funding, improve student outcomes and improve the quality of public education."The other big thing that we're very proud of is having as many students as wish to go ahead and take the Advanced Placement classes and exams," Delean-Botkin said.At a July 19 Talbot County Board of Education meeting, President Emily Jackson said the board wishes Delean-Botkin the best of luck."We will miss her words of wisdom and her guidance," Jackson said.Talbot County Public Schools Executive Assistant Charlene Gould said in an email that the governor's office has been notified of the vacancy and will appoint a new board member to fill Delean-Botkin's seat until elections in November 2024.She said interested candidates can submit an application to the Governor's Appointments Office.In June, Commissioners Tom Costigan and Jimmy Jaramillo appointed Delean-Botkin to fill Commissioner Brian Wells' seat.Wells resigned at the June 27 Commissioners of Oxford meeting. He said he was resigning because he was moving to Easton.Before being appointed, Delean-Botkin ran against and lost to now Commissioner Katrina Greer. Greer took the seat of Jaramillo, who did not seek reelection.Delean-Botkin said her new role as Oxford commissioner is a "challenging" one."I think what we have to look at is, Oxford a town of about 600 folks," she said."Three sides are surrounded by water, so we have limits on growth. People tend to want to move to Oxford because of the quality of life.Majority of people that I talk to do not want to see many things change. They want to maintain the integrity of the town." 
 
 Caption: PHOTO BY MAGGIE TROVATO
 
Susan Delean-Botkin has resigned from the Talbot County Board of Education. 
 
 Memo: "The other big thing that we're very proud of is having as many students as wish to go ahead and take the Advanced Placement classes and exams." - Susan Delean-Botkin

The board expects to fill the vacancy before the next fiscal planning session, ensuring uninterrupted oversight of Talbot County Public Schools.

story.title: New director hired at Chesapeake College in Cambridge
story.content:
New director hired at Chesapeake College in Cambridge

 August 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 442
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Lorelly Solano is combining her interests in education and public policy in her new role as director of the Chesapeake College Cambridge Center."I enjoyed working directly with the students - hearing about their dreams and learning about their challenges while I've helped them plan their academic journeys," Solano said."This new role will be a bit different for me, but I will try to bring that student perspective into everything I do here." As director of the center, located on Race Street, Solano will lead the staff in providing all the services Cambridge-based students need to be successful.In the coming months, Cambridge residents are likely to meet Solano as she begins her community outreach efforts.The Cambridge Center, Solano said, is a resource for everyone in Dorchester County, playing a critical role in the economic and social health of the downtown area.In addition to credit classes in both transfer and career programs, the center offers workforce training, personal enrichment opportunities and meeting spaces for community organizations.The center also houses the American Job Center."We're an education center for students of all ages, but I hope residents here also see us as a center of community growth," Solano said.Solano first joined Chesapeake as an English as a Second Language instructor. She was later the academic and career adviser guiding students through actionable plans to achieve their goals.A native of Costa Rica, Solano came to the United States as a graduate student.After earning her bachelor's degree in Costa Rica, she worked for an international flower exporter as she continued her studies toward licensure at the University of Costa Rica.Her future plans took a turn when a professor at the university asked if she was adventurous.Thinking that the professor meant bungee jumping or some other daredevil sport, Solano prepared to decline. Instead, the professor asked if she would be interested in taking on a new academic challenge in a different country. He recommended her for a graduate research post at the University of Maryland.While working on "green" roof research and earning her master's degree in natural resources science at College Park, Solano's interest grew in building sustainable communities through policy and education.She went on to earn a Ph.D.in public policy and urban affairs at the University of Delaware."It's ironic that I studied urban affairs and ended up in a rural area," Solano said. "Rural and urban areas face many of the same challenges, though, and people in both areas want the same things." Better lives and a greater sense of community, Solano said, are common desires for most people.The Cambridge Center provides both, she added. 
 
 Caption: SUBMITTED.
 
Lorelly Solano is the new director of the Chesapeake College Cambridge Center. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

The appointment aims to strengthen partnerships with local businesses and improve enrollment at the Cambridge site. College officials said the hire reflects a commitment to expanding educational opportunities in the region.

story.title: School district saves thousands in energy costs - Program focuses on use and use reduction
story.author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
story.content:
School district saves thousands in energy costs - Program focuses on use and use reduction

 August 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 17 | Section: News 
 
 581
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - Efforts by Caroline County Public Schools to reduce energy costs have resulted in almost $260,000 in savings as a result of a yearlong program managed by Cenergistic, an energy conservation company based in Dallas, Texas.Reporting at the Aug. 1 meeting of the Caroline County Board of Education, Cenergistic Client Manager Scott Muir shared a slide show depicting how the program has saved the school district money since July 1, 2022.School board president Richard Barton called the first annual report "really exciting stuff." "I've just got to give you guys big kudos," Muir said. "This is one of the fastest and most successful starts to a program that I've seen." Muir and Superintendent Dr.Derek Simmons credited Cenergistic Energy specialist Josh Rein for his work in the district."Having Josh here from the very beginning" was beneficial, Muir said. "Typically we do have a challenge hiring an energy specialist from outside the district, so they have to develop all these relationships and try and do it quickly. And we just got off to a great start with him already knowing everyone here." Cenergistic created the energy conservation program that "assists in minimizing the impact that cost increases has on the budget," according to the report. Four energy sources were considered: electricity, solar, heating oil and propane.The lion's share of cost increases was from electricity the school district buys from the grid at a 64% increase and heating oil with a 42% increase."There's not a whole lot we can do about the costs, so our company focuses on use and use reduction," Muir said.Relying on solar and setting back thermostats on weekends, nights and during the summer made a difference, Muir said.From July 2022 through June 2023, 80% of CCPS's utility spending was on electricity."That's a huge area of focus for Josh and our team," Muir said.However, even with the increases in energy costs, the public schools decreased energy use intensity (EUI) by 35%. Energy use intensity is a measure of 1,000 BTUs of energy per square foot, "a benchmark that the EPA uses," Muir said. It's also used for Energy Star certification."It's a way of measuring elementary schools against other elementary schools, houses against houses, and the regional average here for K12 schools is 54 EUI," Muir said. "When we started the program, you actually were doing pretty well; you were already at 50 EDI. And today, for the last 12 months, we're down to 32 EUI. So at that at that level, our company is going to be looking at getting certified for Energy Star for a lot of facilities." An "energy savings day" on Monday July 3, "was a great little initiative and the results show," Muir said.Rein performed more than 1,516 building audits, "and that equates to 1,451 metric tons of CO2 emissions avoided," Muir said. "That's a huge environmental footprint." Muir compared the 1,451 metric tons of CO2, equating them to "over 3.5 million miles driven by an average car," he said. "That amount of energy can power 175 homes for the year." Cenergistic has a five-year contract with the Caroline County Public Schools."The message to the taxpayer is (our) more efficient use of money, and that's something you don't hear government say very often," Barton said.To view the full report, visit https://go.boarddocs.com/mabe/carps/Board.nsf/Public, open the Aug. 1 agenda and click on the "Cenergistic Update" link. 
 
 Caption: CONNIE CONNOLLY/TIMES RECORD
 
Cenergistic Client Manager Scott Muir shared a slide show depicting how the program has saved the school district over $250,000 since July 1, 2022 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Derek Simmons — Superintendent, Caroline County Public Schools

Launched earlier this year in Caroline County Public Schools, the initiative combines real‑time usage monitoring, LED lighting retrofits, HVAC upgrades, and student‑staff education on conservation. By reducing electricity and gas consumption, the program cut the 2022‑23 budget by an estimated $45,000 and is projected to save an additional $120,000 annually. Officials said the effort demonstrates fiscal responsibility and supports the county’s sustainability goals.

story.title: School board adopts new AP Physics textbook
story.author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
story.content:
School board adopts new AP Physics textbook

 August 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 19 | Section: News 
 
 224
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - The Caroline County Board of Education approved the purchase of a hefty, 1,450-page AP Physics textbook at its Aug. 1 meeting in Denton.The "2018 Fundamentals of Physics," extended 12th edition "aligns with the College Board AP Physics course audit outline and the course framework" and "will serve as a critical support for both teachers and students enrolled" in the high school advanced placement course," the report to the board stated.The board purchased 40 textbooks for $3,375, which includes additional online resources. The authors are D. Halliday, R. Resnick and J. Walker. It is published by John Wiley & Sons.Members of the textbook adoption committee were Supervisor of Instruction Amy Towers, Colonel Richardson High School teacher Chad Shelly, Principal Nikki VonDen-Bosch and parent Nikki Welzel; and North Caroline High School Teacher John Moyer, Principal Matt Spiker and parent Daniell Darling."It's a very small pool of students that we affect in AP Physics," Towers said."Currently, we only have a class at North Caroline with about 10 students in it.We're hoping to build that at Colonel as well, as students do have the opportunity to transition to North Caroline to take that course if necessary." 
 
 Caption: CONNIE CONNOLLY/TIMES RECORD
 
Supervisor of Instruction Amy Towers presents the hefty new AP Physics textbook to Dr. Derek Simmons, superintendent of Caroline County Public Schools Aug. 1. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Superintendent Derek Simmons and Supervisor of Instruction Amy Towers led the decision, citing College Board updates and the need for more rigorous, inquiry‑based content. Teachers Chad Shelly (Colonel Richardson) and John Moyer (North Caroline) praised the resource, while Principal Nikki VonDen‑Bosch said it will support labs and exam preparation. The adoption applies to all AP Physics courses starting fall 2023, aiming to boost student performance and college readiness.

story.title: Dorchester Board of Education Gets Ready for School Year
story.author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
story.content:
Dorchester Board of Education gets ready for school year

 September 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: A14 | Section: News 
 
 511
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - As teachers, students and administrators gear up to go back to school, the Dorchester County Board of Education is looking at how they will approach this school year.At the beginning of the Aug. 17 Board of Education meeting, board members heard school plans from Choptank Elementary School Principal Gave Parker and Mace's Lane Middle School Principal Patricia Prosser.Both principals spoke about their plans to improve schools, including improving student reading levels and decreasing the number of suspensions. Board members asked questions about how the schools plan to track progress, address staffing vacancies and what things the board and community can do to help the schools reach their goals.Throughout the rest of the meeting, board members asked questions, initiated conversations and probed deeper about many of the meeting's agenda items.At the end of the meeting, board member Theresa Stafford gave her hopes for the school year."I hope that as we move forward as a board, the community does not have to guess where we are and where we're going," she said."This year we will be transparent in everything we do." Stafford said conversations are healthy and that hard conversations need to happen."One of the first things in moving forward," she said, "(is) we have to be realistic.And we may not paint a rosy picture that everybody this year is going to sit here and smile and agree." Stafford said that, as board members, listening to the community and supporting teachers is vital."We are the voice of the people who elected us to make sure that we are doing the best we can for the kids we have and for the community that we serve," she said.Board member Chris Wheedleton said he's excited about making data-driven decisions this school year. He said there a plans for a new dashboard that will show whether progress on student outcomes is being made in the district."We're putting ourselves to account and making sure that we can really report where we're seeing progress," he said.Wheedleton also talked about the importance of having civil and constructive conversations as a board. He said that this can go handin-hand with data-driven decision making."I think that's an important message for our kids to hear as we go back into school as well - that civility and data can actually go together," he said. "It's all about us looking at the data and then making really smart decisions about what we do." School Board President Susan Morgan said it's going to take collaboration to effect change."There's no reason that Dorchester County can't be the best county on the Eastern Shore for education," she said. "To do that though, we need a little bit more help.We need help from parents, guardians, grandparents, anyone who has a child in our system." 
 
 Caption: MAGGIE TROVATO/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Dorchester County Board of Education Member Theresa Stafford speaks during a Board of Education meeting Aug. 17 in Cambridge.
 
MAGGIE TROVATO/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Dorchester County Board of Education Member Chris Wheedleton speaks during a Board of Education meeting Aug. 17 in Cambridge. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

The board scheduled quarterly reviews and pledged community outreach to address parental concerns. Decisions aim to ensure a smooth start on Aug. 21 across Dorchester County schools.

story.title: Howie Sworn into Vacant Board of Education Seat
story.author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
story.content:
Howie sworn into vacant Board of Education seat

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 313
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Anna Howie was sworn in as the newest member of the Talbot County Board of Education at a work session Monday evening.The swearing in came nearly a week after Howie was appointed to the seat by Gov. Wes Moore following the resignation of Susan Delean-Botkin, the previous District 5 board member.Howie will serve on the board until early December 2024, when a newly elected member is sworn in.After being sworn in by Talbot County Circuit Court Clerk Kathi Duvall at the work session on Monday, Howie took her seat at the table and the board went into a closed session.Before the board went into closed session, Board President Emily Jackson welcomed Howie to her new office."We're all excited that you're here," Jackson said."And we've got a lot of work to do, so roll up your sleeves." Howie is the curriculum supervisor of career and technical education for Dorchester County Public Schools as well as the interim principal at Mace's Lane Middle School.According to a press release from Talbot County Public Schools, the Talbot County native, who lives in Easton with her husband and children, has 21 years of experience in K-12 education.Howie has a bachelor of industrial engineering from the Georgia Institute of Technology and a master of arts in supervision and administration from the University of Phoenix. She is currently pursuing a doctorate in organizational leadership from the University of Maryland Eastern Shore, according to the press release.The Talbot County Education Association endorsed Howie for the appointment."We submit this recommendation without reservation and with our heartfelt belief that she is an ideal candidate who will serve our community well," Andrew Burke, TCEA president, said in a letter to the governor. 
 
 Caption: MAGGIE TROVATO/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Anna Howie (left) is sworn in to the Talbot County Board of Education by Talbot County Circuit Court Clerk Kathi Duvall at a work session Oct. 16. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Board President Emily Jackson welcomed Howie, noting the appointment restores a full quorum and supports ongoing initiatives such as curriculum updates and teacher‑salary negotiations. story.title: Making History - Students Work Towards National History Day Competition
story.author: Laura Tayman
story.content:
Making history - Students work towards National History Day competition

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman | Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
 486
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE - When Queen Anne's County history teachers Thomas Hayman and Andy Anders first began recruiting students for National History Day years ago, there wasn't a lot of convincing students to participate."We knew we had to up our game," said Anders. "Now the Upper Shore region is second in the state for participation." National History Day is an event that encourages students to develop research, analysis, presentation, and social skills while working on a historical project. Open to students across the Shore, including Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot, working individually or in groups, Junior Division (grades six-eight) and Senior Division (grades nine-12) students select a topic related to an annual theme. Information on the competitive event is distributed to students by their history teachers.The 2024 NHD theme is "Turning Points in History." There are five different types of projects that students complete: documentaries, exhibits, performances, and websites that can be done as a group or individually or papers that may only be done individually.Research is key, so the two teachers partnered with the public libraries in the participating Upper Shore counties of Queen Anne's, Kent, Talbot, and Cecil."Schools have limited research options," said Hayman, "so we turned to the county libraries who have more resources." During the fall season, as students begin picking a theme and looking for information, the teachers make themselves available at libraries across the region on specific dates so that librarians and History Day staff can provide assistance with finding research options, accessing online databases, or browsing materials.Hayman said the students learn valuable skills "like how to analyze information, to make sure sources are reliable, and to form their own opinion." Last weekend, Hayman and Anders visited Queen Anne's Library on Kent Island. Next up is the Talbot County Free Library in Easton on Oct. 21 from 9 a.m. 1 p.m.; Queen Anne's County Library in Centreville from 9 a.m. 1 p.m. on Nov. 4; and the Learning Resource Center at Chesapeake College on Nov. 12 from 1 p.m. to 5 p.m.The actual contest is March 23, 2024, at Chesapeake College. Judges from the Upper-Shore community include teachers, professors, and museum staff. Students who place are then able to participate in the state finals on May 4 at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County.The hard work of Hayman and Anders has paid off. "We saw that at the beginning the winners were always from the western shore," said Anders."Now we send more students to the state event than everyone but Baltimore County." Hayman said the program helps make history more real and interesting to students."You don't usually have students thrilled to be in history class," said Hayman. "Students who participate sometimes find their true passion." 
 
 Caption: LAURA TAYMAN
 
Thomas Hayman and Andy Anders, both history teachers at Centreville Middle School, visit Queen Anne's County Library Kent Island branch on their first stop helping students from the Upper Shore with their History Day project research. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on teachers guiding students in a history competition, emphasizing research, skills development, and school‑library partnerships, which aligns primarily with the Education topic.

key_people: Thomas Hayman — History Teacher, Centreville Middle School
Andy Anders — History Teacher, Centreville Middle School
story.summary: On Oct. 18, 2023, middle‑school students from Queen Anne’s, Talbot, Kent and Cecil counties began intensive projects for the 2024 National History Day competition. History teachers Thomas Hayman and Andy Anders of Centreville Middle School guided participants in researching, writing and presenting original historical topics. The schools, part of Queen Anne’s, Talbot, Kent and Cecil County Public Schools and overseen by the Maryland State Department of Education, coordinated workshops, mentor sessions and a county‑wide showcase. Organizers aim to develop critical thinking and civic engagement, hoping several entries will advance to the state level and ultimately the national contest in Washington, D.C.

story.title: It's in the Family - Anna Howie Speaks on Joining Board of Education
story.author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
story.content:
It's in the family - Anna Howie speaks on joining Board of Education

 October 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 551
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Education is in Anna Howie's blood.Specifically, Talbot County education is in Anna Howie's blood.Her grandfather and mother taught in the district.Her mother was even her sixth grade language arts teacher at Easton Middle School.When Howie, the newest member of the Talbot County Board of Education, went to college, she wanted to be an engineer.However, a career in education just kept chasing her.In college, she became involved with something called 'The Algebra Project,' where she taught students algebra concepts.For a college internship, she worked with students at a middle school.At a college ministry meeting, Howie remembers the speaker saying, "someone in here, you're an engineering student.And you know God told you you're supposed to be a teacher.'" Although she graduated from the Georgia Institute of Technology in engineering, she unsurprisingly found teaching eventually. Her first job in education was teaching at a middle school.Now, Howie is the curriculum supervisor of career and technical education for Dorchester County Public Schools as well as the interim principal at Mace's Lane Middle School.Monday, she was sworn in to the Board of Education after being appointed to the District 5 seat by Gov. Wes Moore. The appointment comes after the resignation of Susan Delean-Botkin, the previous District 5 board member.W hen she learned of the appointment, Howie told her husband first. He was so excited he switched a flight he had for a conference so he could watch her get sworn in on Monday.Howie herself was excited and honored."A little scared at the same time, because this is a huge undertaking and it's extremely important," she said.Howie talked about the importance of being able to support students' social and emotional and mental health, especially after COVID-19."Schools are safe places for a lot of our students," she said. "If I'm hungry, if I'm angry, if I don't know where I'm going to go to sleep tonight, I can't learn." Social and emotional learning is one of the Board's priorities this school year. Its other priorities are increasing academic achievement and teacher retention."There are teacher shortages everywhere right now, and it's so important that we retain the teachers," she said."Because when you have to continually hire new teachers, there is that onboarding process and there is that learning curve." Joining the board, Howie is continuing her mother and grandfather's legacy in Talbot County Public Schools.When Howie was 18, her mother died from breast cancer. She remembers the funeral being "packed" with former students and teachers from the district."There are teachers in this school district that knew my mom when she was here and they come up to me all the time and they're like, 'Your mother would be so proud,'" Howie said, tearing up.With two meetings under her belt so far - a work session on Monday and a regular meeting on Wednesday - Howie is feeling welcomed by her fellow board members.She appreciates the organization of the meetings."Everything went very smooth," she said.Although she's been on the board for less than a week, Howie has already been thinking about whether she will run for the position when her seat is up next year. She doesn't have an answer yet, though."I have definitely, definitely put a lot of thought into that," she said. "This is such a wonderful opportunity."

story.title: CCTC AMP Students Present Designs - Rashad Wilson's Winning Design Adorns Dartboard Cabinet Project
story.content:
CCTC AMP students present designs - Rashad Wilson's winning design adorns dartboard cabinet project

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 1A | Section: News 
 
 458
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY - The seventh cohort of Advanced Manufacturing Program students at Caroline Career and Technology Center recently presented design ideas for their current project, a dartboard cabinet.The winning design was created by Rashad Wilson, and was inspired by the doors one might find hanging in a saloon in the Old West."Rashad's dartboard design offers a new challenge for the class and me," teacher Keith Hale said.Although the students possessed the software and the capability to machine a three-dimensional object like the steer skull and horns, they had never attempted it before. "This design is more challenging than designs created by previous classes," he said.This particular project was generated three years ago when an AMP student approached Hale with the idea of manufacturing dartboard cabinets. Hale and the class were excited to make this idea a reality.Since then, AMP cabinets with dartboard with darts included have been one of AMP's most popular products, selling out even before they were presented.Each time AMP students manufacture a product, they follow the same template.It begins with research, mood-boarding and a product pitch. With dartboards, students research the history, rules and professional leagues in the game of darts. Then each student must come up with a design for the project, followed by drafting their design and placing it on a Mood Board.This Mood Board becomes a visual they can refer to as they present their product pitch.Business partners, school officials, parents and former students are then invited to watch the students' product pitches Oct. 26.One by one, students manage the difficult task of individually pitching the details and merits of their designs to the class and guests in attendance.At the end of the presentations, everyone votes and a design is chosen.The next step in the process is called "napkin sketching," which is a sketch of the product views and dimensions.These sketches are then taken to the computer aided drafting lab, where more accurate prints are made. From those prints, numeric commands are created that will drive a computer numeric control machine, which is a robot programmed to cut pieces out of stock material.Once complete, an audience is once again assembled for student presentations of the finished products, which are also offered for sale.

Visitors and Caroline County Public Schools staff, including Lindsey McCormick, right, and school board member Donna DiGiacomo, second from right, attend an Advanced Manufacturing Program students' presentation Oct. 26 at Caroline Career and Technology Center.

story.title: Apprenticeships Explored at Local High Schools
story.author: Laura Tayman; tayman@chespub.com
story.content:
Apprenticeships explored at local high schools

 November 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman; tayman@chespub.com | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 696
 Words 

 Read News Document

 While high school students are still tasked with learning English, math, history, and science, career apprenticeships are being revitalized in Queen Anne's County and across the country, educating future workers and preparing them with marketable skills sought in high-demand industries.Karen Hesson of Kent Island High School and Betsy Ricketts of Queen Anne's County High School are in their first year serving as their school's Career Coach for students, a new position the county created this year."There is so much information available for students now, and it is hard for them and their families to navigate through it," said Hesson. "We help students identify what interests them and how to get to where they need to be to meet their goals, whether it is college, trade schools, or working directly with businesses to allow students to learn on the job." Hesson and Ricketts worked together on securing a week's worth of visitors available to meet with students during a part of their lunchtime. From military and law enforcement to county government and local businesses who are needing workers with specific skills, all were on hand to answer questions and discuss options for the future.One of the presenters was Connie Dean, the Career Technology Liaison for the Queen Anne's County Economic & Tourism Development department. Dean is assisting the two schools with finding businesses who are interested in the apprenticeship program."Students are first given skills that would be required to work in a certain business field," said Dean. Then the students work 450 hours at a partnering business to earn their official apprenticeship recognition."I try to tell businesses internships are a bigger commitment, when the apprenticeship program would be appropriate for future workers in their field," she said.Currently, there are three Kent Island students who were trained in the culinary department at Chesapeake College this semester.Aly Swann said she learned about the basics like cutting meat, how to work with knives and other kitchen tools, and how to make sauces. "I know now 100% that this is what I want to do for a living," she said.James Smith said the school was really helpful in letting him work some during the school day. "I appreciate that I got a pathway for my career. I have learned skills I will use for a long time," said Smith.Last Tuesday, was military and law enforcement day for the Queen Anne's apprentice week, with recruiters from all armed forces branches, answering questions about basic training, money for college, and traveling the globe.Troopers Christopher Bekefiand Doug Prince provided information on the Maryland State Police Cadet program, where students aged 17-19 are assigned to perform duties that do not require police authority (example helping with crowds at large public events). Cadets are also assigned to work under the supervision of a Trooper at a truck inspection station or on patrol.They also have an explorer program for students aged 14-18, where they are introduced to various divisions and tactics like crime scene investigations, traffic stops, and forensics.Adam Tolley, supervisor of Career and Technology Education for Queen Anne's Public Schools, was pleased to see so many students engaging with a variety of workforce representatives. "This is a very organized way to provide students who are beginning to think about real career options," he said.County Commissioner Philip Dumenil was present to view the new apprentice week program first hand at Queen Anne's High School. "I like new opportunities for exposure to these kind of programs," said Dumenil. "Lots of money can still be made in the trade fields. Not every kid wants to go to college." Queen Anne's student Austin Hahn, just a sophomore, has already chosen a career for his future, and that, said Ricketts, makes him a perfect apprentice candidate.Hahn has chosen to pursue a career in marine mechanics and pipe welding and wishes to move to the Gulf of Mexico in Louisiana or Texas where he has family. "My grandfather taught me a lot about it," said Hahn. "He said it would be the best money I could ever make. When he passed away, I knew I would definitely do it." 
 
 Caption: LAURA TAYMAN
 
New Career Coach Betsy Ricketts stands beside the poster for Queen Anne's County High School's first apprenticeship week schedule. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Career coaches Karen Hesson (Kent Island) and Betsy Ricketts (Queen Anne’s County High) presented data on local labor needs, while Connie Dean, the county’s Career‑Technology Liaison, outlined a pilot program linking schools with the Maryland State Police and regional employers. Sophomores Aly Swann and James Smith shared personal interest in trades and law‑enforcement tracks. County Economic & Tourism Development pledged funding for on‑site training and mentorship. Participants agreed to launch a limited‑scale apprenticeship rollout for the 2024‑25 school year, aiming to increase student employability and address workforce gaps in Queen Anne’s County.

story.title: Caroline Commissioners Approve Summer School Grant
story.author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
story.content:
Caroline Commissioners approve summer school grant

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 17 | Section: News 
 
 512
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - After expressing appreciation for the contributions of public health professionals, the Caroline County Commission held about an hour-long meeting at 9 a.m. Tuesday, Nov. 21.Jamie Beachy, director of Caroline County Recreation and Parks, presented a grant award from the Maryland Department of Education to fund Caroline County summer learning centers.The commissioners accepted the three-year $1.2 million grant."What this means for the first summer year is that we will be looking at five school sites, and unlike our previous years that we targeted 700 students, we will be targeting 1,100 for next summer," Beachy said. "Yes, we are insane. We're fully aware that that's going to be a very big lift for us." Beachy said that for the two years following 2024, "without another funding stream becoming available, we will drop back down to three elementary schools with a total of 400 students." In other business, the commissioners approved a $1,011,834 contract with Nashville-based Wellpath LLC to provide medical services for inmates at the county jail.Two surplus vehicles will be offered for sale, deemed by the County Commissioners to be "no longer needed, outdated, unsafe, or (their) condition has deteriorated to the point that maintenance costs exceeds its practical value." A 2012 Dodge ambulance with 211,797 miles and a 2014 Dodge Ram with 218,742 miles will be auctioned locally.Ryan White has left his position as director of the Department of Public Works, and that position may be reconfigured before it is advertised.Commission Vice President Larry Porter expressed some concern about "the scope of what is going to be able to be done by public works." "At some point, in my opinion, (it's) going to have to be reduced. There's going to have to be more things contracted out," Porter said.Commission President Travis Breeding said, "I've been giving this position a lot of thought, and I think it would be helpful to have someone there who is wellversed in the design process, permitting process, bid process.I almost feel like it's a two-person role." The next Caroline County Commission meeting will be held 9 a.m. Tuesday, Dec.5, in Room 106, Caroline County Courthouse, 109 Market St., Denton.Meetings are held 9 a.m.Tuesdays except the fifth Tuesday of the month, unless announced otherwise. Meetings are open to the public for attendance. Attendees will be security screened as they enter the courthouse.All Commission agendas with hyperlinks to documents can be found at www.carolinemd.org.The public can also attend meetings and work sessions remotely via ZOOM at https://zoom. us/j/300062187. The tollfree phone numbers to dial in are 888-475-4499 or 877-853-5257, and the meeting ID number is 300 062 187. 
 
 Caption: COURTESY OF CAROLINE COUNTY COMMISSIONERS
 
The Caroline County Commissioners recognize National Apprenticeship Week Nov. 13 to 19 in Caroline County. The week celebrates the power of apprenticeships as a vital workforce training model, empowering individuals to gain valuable skills and secure higher incomes. The commissioners offered thanks to Bilbrough's Electric, Bob Breeding General Contractors, Choptank Electric and Lywood Electric for their commitment to sponsoring active registered apprenticeship programs and shaping the workforce of tomorrow in the Caroline community.

story.title: Ccps Sophomores Explore Career Options At Rotary Fair
story.content:
Ccps Sophomores Explore Career Options At Rotary Fair

 December 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
 562
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - Caroline County Public Schools sophomores explored career options at the Denton Rotary's 2023 Youth Career Exploration Fair Nov. 21 at the General James F. Fretterd Community Center.A number of Caroline County Public School sophomores had the opportunity to visit with representatives from a variety of businesses and attend workshops to help them explore career possibilities before they graduate from high school.Hosted by the Rotary Club of Denton, the 10th Grade Career Exploration Fair was sponsored by Smiles by Holsinger, Shore United Bank, Summit Community Bank and Sisk Fulfillment.The Denton Rotary has been providing this yearly event to 10th grade students since 2013; however, the COVID pandemic temporarily suspended it."The purpose of the event is to spark an interest and open up career possibilities to our 10th graders so they can be career ready when they graduate," said Sue Simmons, a Denton Rotarian and the event chair.This year was the highest attendance ever, with 97 students from Colonial Richardson High School, North County High School and the Caroline Career and Technology Center, who were split up into groups for the day. Nearly 30 small and large businesses set up vendor exhibits.Each group was assigned to a table with a business mentor - an adult to help match them with possible careers that are compatible with their interests or expose them to new ideas and opportunities to consider.Students were encouraged to explore careers that match their personal interests, such as working outside, being a problem solver, caring for others or owning their own business.Each student also attended two of the four workshops that were offered. Workshops included "Unlocking Your Potential at Chesapeake College" by Marci Leach, director of program development at Chesapeake Community College, and J.P. Kelly, business and industry navigator at Chesapeake Community College; "Mental Health Means Inner Wealth" by Sara Porter-Lepore, LCSW-C, and Cara Calloway, mental health coordinator for CCPS; "How To Rock a Job Interview" by Deborah Boulden, youth outreach coordinator for the Upper Shore Workforce Investment Board; and "Way to Be: Exploring Career Interests" by Abigail Trice, Next Generation Scholars coordinator for Caroline County.Participating students also had the opportunity to meet students from other schools, as each group was pre-assigned to their tables by Lindsey McCormick, CCPS director of college and career.Ten juniors who attended the fair last year returned as mentors to help guide the sophomores through the day.A bonus to the program was a special visit from Devon Beck, an NCHS graduate, songwriter, hip hop artist, podcaster and Talbot County Public Schools Equity Facilitator. Beck shared with the students his own story and provided a positive message about being true to themselves and finding a career that is meaningful to them.The Rotary Club of Denton thanked Dr. Derek Simmons, McCormick and Robert Gowen from the CCPS Board of Education; Eric Cook, Ann Ferkler, and Brad Plutschak from CCPS; as well as table mentors Danielle Forrest of Shore United, Linda Prochaska of Appleseed Books, Victor Reynolds of CASA of Caroline, Richard Warfield of the Caroline Review, Esther Curtis of SUN Behavioral Health), Desiree Jefferson and America McKinney of His Hope Ministries, Kristi English of APG Media Chesapeake, Angel Perez of the Caroline Culinary Arts Center, Kat Stork of Shore Strategies LLC, and Sarah Kilmon of Talbot County Communications.

story.title: Caroline Students Earn Biliteracy Credentials
story.author: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub.Com
story.content:
Caroline Students Earn Biliteracy Credentials

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub.Com | Page: 10 | Section: News 
 
 277
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - The Caroline County Board of Education recognized 17 Caroline County students for earning the Global Seal of Biliteracy.The language credential is issued in collaboration with a school or organization and the Global Seal of Biliteracy, an independent international certifying body. It can be awarded to anyone, student or adult, from any state or country, who has met the criteria for one of its two award levels on one of its qualifying tests.
"This is the first time in Caroline County that we have students to obtain the Global Seal of Biliteracy," said Jon Marketto, Caroline County Public Schools supervisor of instruction.
The students achieved "a high standard of proficiency in two or more languages to earn advanced placement, to apply for scholarships or study abroad programs and to access employment opportunities or pay differentials," Marketto said.
The students are Emmy Brown-Varon, Jansy Lorenzo, Joanna Santizo-Morales, Nelvin Tomas, Nayeli Vasquez-Tomas, Maria Ramirez Perez, Sofia Ramirez Gonzalez, Kelly Perez Reyes, Shari, Macario Deleon, Anahi Lopez Salas, Ingrid Domingo Mendez, Ingrid Diaz, Renata Diaz Gomez, Yamileth Benitez Cordova, Shirley Cifuentes-Bautista, Stephanie Alfaro and Ximena Castro Bautista.
"I am so proud of these students," said North Caroline High School Spanish language teacher Mirta Valdes-Bradner. "There was 100% participation in the test, which is a requirement in my course, and 100% passing scores for North Caroline High School."
In June Valdes-Bradner received the 2023 Minority Recognition Award from the Maryland State Educators Association. She was Caroline County's 2022-2023 Teacher of the Year and has taught in the county since 2003.

story.title: School Board Posts Highlights, Next Meetings
story.content:
School board posts highlights, next meetings

 January 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 12 | Section: News

 DENTON - The Caroline County Board of Education met Dec. 5 and elected board officers and heard reports. The Times-Record previously reported on the superintendent's budget priorities, the Rotary Club of Denton's career fair and other agenda items.In addition to previously reported news, the board office posted the following highlights on its website.
Board President Rick Barton and Vice President Jones were reelected.
Chief Finance Officer Erin Thornton provided a finance report to the Board for the period ending Nov. 30, 2023. Ms. Thornton explained that CCPS was five months into the fiscal year and has spent approximately 74% of the budget, which is in line with last year's figures. She explained overages in the following categories: Special Education, projected employee salary versus the cost of hiring contractors; Transportation salaries reflect a change in how payroll is calculated and bus drivers on long term leave, resulting in a need for substitute drivers Capital outlay explained by CCPS Director of Operations William Mengel in previous meetings regarding unexpected capital costs.
The next January meetings of the Board of Education will be 6 p.m. Tuesday, Jan. 9 at the central office, 204 Franklin St., Denton, and 6 p.m. Tuesday, Jan. 16, for a work session with the Caroline County Commissioners.
Meetings are open to the public as well as livestreamed.
For more information and instructions on submitting public comments, visit www.carolineschools.org/o/ccps/page/board#schedule.

story.title: Radcliffe Creek School Awarded 'Social-Emotional' Learning Grant
story.author: Staff Writer
story.content:
Radcliffe Creek School awarded 'social-emotional' learning grant

 January 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 534
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Radcliffe Creek School (RCS) was recently awarded a grant from the Queen Anne's County Mental Health Committee (QACMHC) to expand its social-emotional learning curriculum. The new funding will broaden the robust curriculum already in place for younger students, bringing social-emotional resources to older students and their parents, as well as to the local community.Social-emotional skills serve as a guide for people to understand social situations and relationships: these abilities are central to navigating the world successfully in everyday life. Debbie Cohee-Wright, a special education learning specialist at RCS explained, "If a child has a mental health issue of any kind, such as trauma, depression or anxiety, their ability to learn and access information is compromised. For a student to be available for learning, they must first feel emotionally safe. Making connections with teachers and peers and building trust with others must happen before the focus on academics can take place."
Currently, the school's social-emotional learning program encompasses two curriculums targeted to younger students who are identified as needing support to strengthen these skills. The program, administered by Intervention Transition Skills Coach Bryn Ponti, utilizes fun, engaging activities that integrate kid- friendly themes: kids imagine themselves as detectives who look for clues in their environment or as superheroes who earn superpowers, all while learning about executive functioning, perspective taking and self-regulation.
Head of School Peter Thayer said, "At RCS, we always try to meet students where they are in their learning, and here, that includes their social-emotional wellbeing. This grant from QACMHC will make a considerable difference in the lives of our older students and their families, many of whom are neurodivergent and need extra support in this area."
The funding provided by QACMHC will bring two additional curriculums—Brain Talk and Conscious Discipline—to the school, expanding its social-emotional programming to older students and their families.
Brain Talk is a curriculum designed to teach students about the different areas of their brains, educating children about their executive function capabilities and how they impact responses to situations.
Conscious Discipline is a course designed for teachers, parents and guardians, providing adults with tools to show children better ways to self-regulate and build resilience.
"These grants are made possible by community support of our fundraisers and through generous donations from local businesses and individuals," QACMHC President Kelly Phipps said. "We appreciate the outpouring of support whenever we have a fundraiser or ask for donations."
In addition to the new resources this grant will provide to Radcliffe Creek School's teachers, students and their families, the QACMHC grant will allow RCS to bring social-emotional programming to the local community as well. Planning is already underway to host an event for the public, bringing this important topic to local parents, teachers and residents in 2024. "We are so grateful to QACMHC for their support of our school's social-emotional learning program. These funds will directly impact our students' mental health by supporting children both in the classroom and at home, leading to a more positive school environment, a greater sense of empowerment among our teachers and parents, and an increased sense of confidence in our children. We are excited to bring these resources to the Radcliffe Creek School community and beyond in 2024," remarked Director of Advancement Carolyn Thompson. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

story.title: 'Diving Deep' with Dyslexia: Local Special Education Teacher Works to Raise Awareness
story.author: Tamara Forte Special to the Star Democrat
story.content:
'Diving Deep' with dyslexia: Local special education teacher works to raise awareness

 January 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 1217
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — What do Robin Williams, Jay Leno, Albert Einstein, Alexander Graham Bell, Magic Johnson, Jennifer Aniston, Gwen Stefani, Abraham Lincoln, and Arnold Schwarzenegger all have in common? They all have dyslexia.Lindsey Parte, a mother of two boys and Special Education teacher, has reignited the Decoding Dyslexia Maryland Eastern Shore Chapter that fizzled out during the Covid pandemic.
Parte shares that she has been "diving deep into advocating and teaching herself (about dyslexia)" for the last three years.
When Parte's older son, Lincoln, was six years old, he struggled with both speech and reading. Parte said a red flag to her son's learning struggle was "knowing how smart he was but not understanding why reading was so hard."
Parte explains that her two-year younger son was making gains on her older son. In contrast, reading was coming with ease to her younger son.
On the first day of second grade, Lincoln (her older son) came home and said, "I can't do this. I can't read. I hate school." Lincoln was frustrated with learning and wanted to quit.
It was heartbreaking for Parte as a mother and as a special education teacher herself as no one wants to see their child struggle, especially with learning. Parte explained, reading is the gateway to learning and lifelong success, and as such, learning to read successfully is vital to all.
Two years after Parte first suspected Lincoln was dyslexic, Lincoln got his formal diagnosis. Parte explained that getting the diagnosis meant freedom for her and her son.
She recounts, "I will never forget the utter sigh of relief when we told him he has dyslexia. It all made sense to him from that moment on. Within a week, he was already talking about it in class and advocating for himself. And most importantly, we got our boy back. His light turned back on."
According to the Mayo Clinic, dyslexia is "a learning disorder that involves difficulty reading due to problems identifying speech sounds and learning how they relate to letters and words (decoding). Also called a reading disability, dyslexia is a result of individual differences in areas of the brain that process language."
An MRI shows the physical differences in the brain composition of a dyslexic thinker versus a non-dyslexic thinker. Dyslexia is so common that one in five people are a dyslexic learners.
What is it like to have dyslexia? How can I help and support a dyslexic learner? What are the early indicators of dyslexia? These questions and many others will be answered at 6:30 p.m., Feb. 20, at the "Experience Dyslexia: A Dyslexia Simulation" workshop at the Queen Anne's County Library Kent Island Branch location.
The free event, hosted by Decoding Dyslexia Maryland Eastern Shore Chapter, aims to raise dyslexia awareness, empower families to support their children, encourage educational interventions, and ultimately influence policy makers to support Maryland students with dyslexia.
All are welcome. The event will offer six stations to help understand the dyslexic learner: Learn to Read, Listen to Me, Write with Mirrors, Name the Letter, Write or Left, and Unfair Hearing Test.
Parte says,"The two biggest takeaways I have learned over the last year of my deep dive into my son's brain and the way he learns are early identification is crucial (as young as five-years-old); and the dyslexic brain requires instruction to be explicit, systematic, cumulative and multisensory.
"It should integrate the teaching of listening, speaking, reading, spelling, vocabulary, fluency, handwriting and written expression. There should be an emphasis on the structure of language: phonology, orthography, morphology, syntax and semantics. Training teachers and educating parents is also of the utmost importance," she continued.
Since then, Lincoln has helped his mom set up and lead workshops. In October, to celebrate Dyslexia Awareness Month, this mother and son duo led the Halloween-themed workshop entitled "There is nothing scarier than not being able to read."
Parte believes in dyslexia awareness and education with her whole being, which is why she fundraised, on her own, to purchase the upcoming workshop materials.
After more than three years of advocating, Parte promotes all adults to learn as much as they can by listening to podcasts, attending free trainings, reading books and fact sheets, and much more.
Moving forward, what steps can we take?
"Release the stigma. Embrace the label," Parte said. "The label means freedom. It gives a child the right to read. The right to appropriate instruction which in turns means success in reading and regaining self confidence. We got our child back the moment we told him he had dyslexia. The label opens a world of resources for your child to feel good about themselves. Priority is a child's mental and social wellbeing."
Dyslexic Learners have many strengths and show a lot of leadership skills. Some other positive skills of dyslexic learners include: problem-solving, big picture thinking, creativity, empathetic, and entrepreneurial skills.
Parte shared things parents can do to help their struggling reader if they suspect their child has dyslexia:
Testing is everything. You will be surprised how relieved your child is with a "diagnosis".
Finding the right intervention specialist (tutors in reading are not the same as someone trained and certified in structured reading interventions like Orton Gillingham). Tutoring at least three times a week is most effective. The key to remediation is "go as fast as you can and as slow as you need to". Early intervention is crucial especially to maintain your child's confidence in school.
Deep dive in your own research. It will help with advocacy, ensuring the right assessments are being used, and knowing the right questions to vet organizations and other folks who claim to want to help your student.
Read to your child not so they learn to read but so that they develop their reading comprehension and vocabulary while they are learning to read with appropriate interventions.
If your child receives the diagnosis of dyslexia, tell them, she encourages. Share all the amazing qualities a dyslexic thinker has and famous people who have dyslexia. Show them a photograph of a dyslexic brain vs typical brain.
Knowledge and support in this process are so important. You don't have to go through this emotional journey alone. Connect with your local Decoding Dyslexia chapter.
Parte explains, "Most children with dyslexia can succeed in school with tutoring or a specialized education program. Emotional support also plays an important role.
Though there's no cure for dyslexia, early assessment and intervention result in the best outcome. Sometimes dyslexia goes undiagnosed for years and isn't recognized until adulthood, but it's never too late to seek help."
Community support, awareness, education, and training will help all our learners learn in the best ways to be successful, happy learners. Together, we can impact our future and the future of our children. If you cannot attend the workshop at the library but are interested in gaining resources and learning more, you can email decodingdyslexiaES@gmail.com for more information and for a Welcome Newsletter with a list of more resources.
Currently, Decoding Dyslexia Maryland Eastern Shore Chapter is a grassroots movement (not a nonprofit), which means it has no funding and is paid for all out-of-pocket. It is run by parents who are also working professionals.
"The fight continues," Parte said, "Until every single child (and their families) don't have to go through this hell and back to learn how to read."
To support and make a donation to Decoding Dyslexia Maryland Eastern Shore Chapter, you can also email Parte at the email above. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

story.title: DCTC Masonry Instructor Surprised by Coworkers on Last Day
story.author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
story.content:
DCTC Masonry instructor surprised by coworkers on last day

 January 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 738
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — On his last day of teaching at the Dorchester Career and Technology Center, Masonry Instructor Eddie Bailey wasn't the only one sporting a baseball cap, grey sweatshirt and jeans.More than 10 of his coworkers showed up and showed out in Bailey's well-known uniform. Some of his doppelgängers even brought their own fake metal detectors — a hobby of Bailey's.
After eight years teaching at DCTC, Bailey is hanging up his trowel and picking up his metal detector.
"You know, I love metal detecting, so I'll probably go find the Holy Grail or something," he said about what he will do in his retirement.
When Bailey came in for his last day of teaching, right before winter break began, it took a little while for him to figure out what his coworkers had done.
"I'm like, 'Wait a minute, something don't look right,'" he said. "Then, when I saw the metal detectors, I was like, 'Ohh, they got me good!'"
DCTC Principal Ashley Robinson came up with the idea.
"I was just trying to really think about how we could celebrate his time here in a way that he would enjoy and that he would feel appreciated," she said. "So I really thought the best way to do that would be with humor, since that's something he really enjoys."
In order to keep it a surprise, Robinson said she made it a part of the school's holiday spirit week.
"So he thought everyone was just dressing in comfy sweatshirts," she said. "And I let everyone else know we were really just dressing like Mr. Bailey."
Bailey, who was surprised by his coworkers' plan, thought it was funny.
"It was so great because I wasn't expecting it," he said. "I would have never expected that."
Bailey said he knew Robinson had something to do with it.
"She comes up with such cool stuff," he said, adding that she gave him a plaque with a trowel on it to commemorate his time teaching at DCTC.
He said there's a reason he would wear the similar outfit that his coworkers knew so well to work everyday.
"Working in the masonry, you can't really go in there with real good clothes on," he said. "You gotta wear your oldest stuff. Like, inside my car, all you see is dust."
Robinson said Bailey, like the rest of DCTC's staff members, epitomizes the importance of CTE education.
"The majority of the teachers here have worked in industry in their field, they have those life experiences and then they chose to come back and give back and work with kids to set them up to be successful," she said. "We were happy to have (Bailey) and happy that he was able to do this."
Bailey has had a few different careers over the years. He owned a masonry business, was a prison guard and spent four years in the Marine Corps. But teaching is in Bailey's blood. His father taught at James M. Bennett High School in Salisbury.
"He was football coach, track coach," Bailey said. "And we lived right across the street from Bennett, so I was at school every day. I knew it from top to bottom."
He has memories of cigarette smoke "flying out of the teachers' lounge" and teachers coming over to his family's house to play cards with his father.
"I mean, that was the good old days," he said.
Looking toward his retirement, Bailey has plans to further explore the hobby his DCTC coworkers know he loves.
Bailey said the Career and Technology Center staff knew about his metal detecting because he would send them photos of some of his finds.
Over the last five years, Bailey said he has gotten more and more into metal detecting. His neighbors, known as The Hoover Boys on YouTube, post metal detecting videos. They have over 100,000 YouTube subscribers. When they moved next door, Bailey said they started giving him their hand-me-downs.
Over the years, Bailey has found all sorts of things — from shoe buckle frames to Civil War bullets to cannonballs. Two of his major finds were a rare George Washington inaugural button and a pine tree shilling.
Although he has plans to do more detecting, Bailey said he'll miss his students.
"A lot of them played sports, and I'd hook them up with a sub," he said. "It was always a sub, a red Gatorade, orange Doritos."
As he moves on to his next chapter, Bailey now has fond memories of his own teaching experience to look back on.
"Oh I loved it," he said.

story.title: KCPS Calendar Approved with Post Labor Day Start
story.author: Staff Writer
story.content:
KCPS calendar approved with post Labor Day start

 February 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 284
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Kent County Board of Education has approved the calendar for the 2024-25 school year.As required by the State of Maryland, the approved calendar includes 180 instruction days for students. Two inclement weather days are built into the calendar.
The 2024-25 school year will begin with a staggered start.
Students in first through sixth grades and ninth-graders will begin school Tuesday, Sept. 3, the day after Labor Day. The first day for students in 10th, 11th and 12th grades is Wednesday, Sept. 4. Pre-kindergartners and kindergartners start school Thursday, Sept. 5.
Longer breaks during the year are Thanksgiving, Nov. 27 through Dec. 1; winter break, Dec. 21 through Jan. 1; and spring break April 17 to April 21.
Additional observed holidays are Martin Luther King Day Monday, Jan. 20; Presidents Day Monday, Feb. 17; and Memorial Day, Monday, May 26.
There are half days and days off in the calendar for staff professional development.
The last day of school is Thursday, June 12. That will be a half day for students.
The full 2024-25 calendar is available for view and download at kent.k12.md.us.
The calendar was developed with input from a committee led by Dan Hushion, supervisor of human resources, and comprising Kent County Public Schools staff and parents.
Staff and community input was sought through two online surveys throughout the development process.
Two drafts calendars were presented to the Board of Education at its meeting Feb. 12, both with post-Labor Day starts.
Survey results showed that of the 327 survey respondents, 75% preferred the calendar that ultimately received the Board of Education's unanimous approval during a meeting Feb. 12.
The other draft, which received 25% of the votes, had longer breaks throughout the school year with last day of school being Friday, June 20. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

story.title: School Board Adopts 2024-2025 Calendar
story.author: Connie Connolly
story.content:
School board adopts 2024-2025 calendar

 February 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 743
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline County students will be heading back to school before Labor Day this year.Offered two alternatives — a pre- or post-Labor Day start — the five-member Board of Education voted unanimously Feb. 6 to approve the pre-Labor Day calendar for the 2024-2025 school year.
English, Spanish and Haitian Creole translations of the calendar are posted on the Caroline County Public Schools website.
The school year start date is Wednesday, Aug. 28.
CCPS Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons presented the two calendars, along with results of a survey distributed to parents, teachers and staff.
While the current school year calendar began after Labor Day, the school board considered factors that mitigated against the later start, including the presidential election day, which necessitates closing schools Tuesday, Nov. 5, and Christmas falling on a Wednesday.
Fall sports practices will begin Aug. 14. Winter break will begin Dec. 20.
The calendar committee emailed a link to the survey Jan. 12 to over 5,400 parents, guardians and all CCPS staff members. A reminder email was sent Jan. 22, and the survey was closed Jan. 26. Some community members provided feedback, as well.
Although 75% of the 3,500 parents and guardians who responded favored a post-Labor Day start, 696 staff respondents, or 70% preferred a pre-Labor Day start.
Before reviewing the feedback, Simmons cautioned the school board, saying, "No matter what decision you make, you're going to make people upset, period. There is no perfect calendar, period."
Board member and retired Caroline County teacher Donna DiGiacomo favored the earlier start.
"So, one calendar starts Aug 28; the other starts Sept. 3, but the end date is just one day difference," DiGiacomo said. The adopted calendar gets "students in a routine quicker, and you have a shorter week when you start — you have three days, so everybody's not dead by Friday."
She said a 4-day first day of school "doesn't sound like a lot, but it's a lot."
Winter break begins with a half-day Friday, Dec. 20, and students returning to school Jan. 7.
"A hard shutdown over winter break for two solid weeks" would result in reduced heating costs and "significant savings" during "the hardest budget year we're going to have," Simmons said.
The post-Labor Day calendar would have had students returning Thursday, Jan. 2, 2025.
"This might not be a popular thing to say, but the reality is not a whole lot is going to get done on that Thursday and Friday," DiGiacomo said.
Other factors influencing the pre-Labor Day start were academic quarter dates and required parent-teacher conferences, which "we talked about ad nauseum," Simmons said.
Calling the process "wonky" and comparing it to a game of dominoes, Simmons explained the factors that prompted the calendar committee to go through "seven or eight drafts to get down to the two that made the most sense."
For example, the first quarter parent-teacher conference day will occur Nov. 5, even though it's election day, because the first quarter ends Nov. 8 and the conference day "has to fall before the first report card goes out, before grades are secured," Simmons said.
The adopted calendar has four inclement weather days built in. If they are not used, they come off the calendar.
State law, teacher contracts, mandatory conferences, state testing days, a set number of half-days, a mid-year transition day all dictate certain days off. Once all of the days off are built in, "it becomes a game of counting to 90 twice" to achieve a state-mandated 180-day school year, Simmons said.
DiGiacomo recommended surveying students next year and considering staggered starts for sixth grade and ninth grade students as they change schools.
"The pluses of draft two are just not as many as the pluses in draft one," said Rick Barton, president of the school board.
Although he liked "the idea of a longer break," school board Vice President Mark Jones was ambivalent.
"I honestly don't like either one of them, really," he said.
That ambivalence was reflected in the overall survey results, with 54% of all respondents preferring a post-Labor Day start and 46% going with the pre-Labor Day calendar.
Anticipating mixed reactions from the public and staff as well, Jones asked, "When do we want to hear complaints? Do we want to hear them right before the first day of school, or do we want to hear them after Christmas break? I think I'd probably rather hear them at the beginning of the year and get it out of the way."
To view the 2024-2025 CCPS school year calendar, visit www.carolineschools.org/page/ccps-school-calendar. The calendars are available in English, Spanish and Haitian Creole.

story.title: Get a Sneak Peek at Chesapeake Forum's Spring Lineup
story.author: Staff Writer
story.content:
Get a sneak peek at Chesapeake Forum's spring lineup

 March 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Events 
 
 260
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Chesapeake Forum's Preview Party will be held April 3, when its Spring 2024 class lineup will be unveiled at the Academy Art Museum in Easton from 3:30 to 5 p.m.The festive, catered event offers guests a chance to hear from Chesapeake Forum instructors, learn what's new and find out more about the program.
There are more than 30 classes on tap this spring through Chesapeake Forum, from birding to car maintenance.
Wayne Bell is back with his popular birding class, this time concentrating on the spring songbird migration. Several veteran teachers are also returning with new classes, including investment opportunities for seniors, more about the Civil War in Maryland, edible flowers, ancient Greek dramas, basic car maintenance and much more. Classes are usually one to three sessions, and in most cases, they can be attended in person at the Easton Family YMCA, on ZOOM or watched on a recording.
Registration begins April 4. Classes start on April 11.
In addition to classes, "Lectures on the Shore," Chesapeake Forum's speaker series, returns on May 9 with "Lights, Camera, Action," the story of the extraordinary Fine family — two generations of award-winning filmmakers.
Community members are invited to come along as the Fines journey through more than 40 years of documentary filmmaking, including the Oscar-winning "Inocente."
The mission of the Chesapeake Forum is to provide lifelong learning opportunities for residents of the Eastern Shore. The organization recently merged with the YMCA of the Eastern Shore.
The event on April 3 is free, but registration is required at chesapeakeforum.org.
To receive Chesapeake Forum's newsletter, send your contact information to info@chesapeakeforum.org.

 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — Nearly 200 local middle and high school students participated in the annual regional history day event held once again at Chesapeake College.Organized by Queen Anne's County Public Schools teacher Thomas Hayman, the March 23 event welcomed 30 area teachers and a troupe of volunteers who hosted six schools. Schools participating in this year's event represented Caroline, Cecil, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties. This year's theme was Turning Points in History.
Projects entered this year covered a wide range of topics, as students used a lot of creativity to make their cases.
Topics covered included pop-culture history, topics related to women's rights and the Great Depression, as well as improvement in technology and even the advent of fast-food and its impact on history.
The students work hard to get to this level of the competition by first competing at the local level within their home school. The next step is this regional event, with the winners invited to participate in the Maryland statewide competition.
At each level, judges provide feedback the students can use to improve their project for the next competition.
Hayman says the event started as an after-school program he became involved in when he first began his teaching career. As the number of students grew, and the national event began to take shape, local programs also grew.
Eastern Shore counties previously had individual county-level events, but they decided to form a coalition in 2017 in order to be more competitive at the state level.
The plan worked — Hayman reports in the five years the Upper Shore Regional event has been held, two area students have gone on to compete in the national event.
The regional event sends the top two from each category, from each county to the state event. The state only sends the top two in each category to the national event.
The event is offered in conjunction with National History Day and Maryland Humanities, and it is intended to help foster a love of history in the students who participate. Students submit projects in five categories: Paper (Individual), Website, Performance, Documentary and Exhibit.
They can submit content as either individuals or in groups of up to five students. There are now three divisions — a youth division for students in the fifth grade, the Junior Division for students of grades six to eight and the Senior Division for students grades nine to 12.
The regional event is funded by Maryland Humanities, which is also responsible for hosting the state event. Hayman said Chesapeake College also played a vital role, donating the space for the exhibits, presentations and performances free of charge — a location providing a more central location than previous venues. Food trucks rounded out the day's festivities for the students.
These students make a choice to put in extra hours to work on their projects outside of their normal school work, Hayman said. Many of the students who participate, come back multiple years to compete, each year improving their research and presentation skills. The amount of effort and dedication these projects require rivals similar science contests.
While not all participants went home with an award, the judges handed out over 50 awards to the students, including: Sports History Award, Heritage Award, Natural History Award, Military History Award, Contemporary World History Award, African American History Award, Colonial History Award, Equality in History Award, Medical History Award, and the Chesapeake Bay/Maritime Award. First, second and third place finishes as well as Best in Region awards were also given in each category.
