story.title: Chesapeake College Honors Class of 2025
story.author: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com
story.content:
Chesapeake College honors Class of 2025

 May 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 496
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — Skipjacks sailed toward promising new horizons as the 2025 Chesapeake College commencement recognized 260 graduates, with 135 walking, on May 21.College President Clifford Coppersmith welcomed the Class of 2025, epitomizing the can-do Skipjack spirit. He encouraged graduates to never fear, embrace hard work and maintain connections.
"Everyone has to start somewhere, and sometimes the correct way is not the easiest," Coppersmith said. With its legacy of watermen and farmers, the Eastern Shore is known even today for its strong work ethic, he said.
Keynote speaker, former U.S. Sen. Ben Cardin, was presented the college's Community Service Award in recognition of his service as a senior statesman, his Chesapeake Bay protection efforts, his dedication to human and civil rights, and his staunch advocacy for higher education.
"Graduation marks a profound turning point in your life. It is not only the culmination of hard work and dedication, but also the beginning of a new chapter filled with opportunity. What you do with that opportunity is up to you," Cardin said.
"Embrace hope," Cardin said, noting the student body was stronger due to its diversity. "Never give up hope for a stronger, more inclusive, more equitable society," he said.
Cardin urged graduates to recognize history lessons as more than words in textbooks, but as guides on what not to do and on how ordinary individuals can be extraordinary.
"As graduates, you have the tools to think globally and act locally. You are the architects of a world where hope becomes reality," he said.
For her breakthroughs in pushing learning past the pages of textbooks, including unforgettable methods of blending academic rigor with applied learning and creative applications, the inaugural Adjunct Innovative Teaching Award was presented to Cherie Patchett, instructor of psychology.
Opening eyes to the world of psychology, Patchett's impact was also noted to extend beyond the classroom, supporting students by establishing a mental health club on campus.
Patchett encouraged graduates to embrace their individuality to innovate their lives.
The John T. Harrison Award was presented to 2025 graduate Cianni A. Phillips for her dedication and empathy. She exemplified true leadership qualities by developing student-focused campus communities.
Phillips is a member of the Phi Theta Kappa Honor Society and is on the Dean's List with a 3.8 GPA.
Phillips served on the Student Government Association, was president of the UHURU Black Student Union, and, in addition to numerous student clubs, served as a student worker in the Office of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion. She will transfer to Coppin State University in Baltimore to pursue a bachelor's degree in social work.
Looking upon the graduating class, Phillips noted the students balanced all manner of life, including jobs and families, along with their schoolwork, to successfully earn a place at the commencement, which was more than a ceremony — it was a celebration and victory, she said.
Moving forward, Phillips encouraged her classmates to continually build support networks, pour back into the community, and be the representation so strongly needed.
"Young people need to see what their futures can be," she said.

story.title: 'Green School' Programs in Caroline County Bring Joy to Students
story.author: Ahmad Garnett
story.content:
'Green School' programs in Caroline County bring joy to students

 May 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chesoub.com | Section: News 
 
 611
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — As of this year, Two Caroline County public schools have been certified as Green Schools by the Maryland Association for Environmental and Outdoor Education.Denton Elementary joined Greensboro Elementary in gaining the certification this year. Both schools went through a two-year application process through MAEOE to be come Green School certified.
Although directors for programs at the schools said the program was intense, they said the help they received from the community was surprising and made the process go much smoother.
"You have to work together, and we divided and conquered," said Julie Strange, pre-k teacher at and program coordinator for Green Schools at Denton Elementary. "You have to contact people at the board office. You have to contact contact your cafeteria. You have to contact people I didn't even know did jobs.
"It's an intense process, but again, eye-opening how helpful everybody was and that there are people for everything."
Within that application for the program there are different subcategories for which the schools must show evidence they met the objective.
The application also comes with a curriculum that must be completed by the students, and the school must provide one example of outdoor or environmental instruction per grade level.
"Through our curriculum and standards, we're able to teach these kids sustainability practices and how to take care of the Earth, just learning about the Earth through those environmental literacy standards. It's one of my passions. I really enjoy doing it," said Zellie Kneller Kidigarden, a teacher and program director for Green Schools at Greensboro Elementary.
Throughout the application process, the elementary schools have been able to produce multiple projects that help compost, save energy and grow fresh foods.
One project at Denton Elementary involves collecting breakfast bags in the morning after breakfast. According to Strange, the school lets third graders create boxes and put recycle signs on them to put in their classrooms to collect bags in the morning.
"Every day, we get breakfast in plastic bags per child, and our school is about 650 kids. So that's 650 bags that go in the trash every day," Strange said. "The kids were so excited about it, and they did it... the kids are responsible for putting their bag in there when they're done their breakfast instead of throwing it in the trash."
One of the projects Greensboro Elementary conducts is planting in multiple gardens.
"We do strawberries, herbs in our garden tower and then we have our pollinator garden. Our Environmental Club also planted native plants everywhere in our swales. Before the end of the school year, we're going to plant native plants in our courtyard," Kneller said.
Kneller credits community partners for being helpful in their pursuit to becoming a green school.
Some of the organizations Greensboro Elementary has partnered with are Pickering Creek Audubon Center, Chesapeake Bay Foundation, Tuckahoe State Park, Wetlands on Wheels and many more.
"I'm so grateful that we're a community school because being a community school allows us to work with... stakeholders in the community, and we get wonderful things from all the members in the community," Kneller said.
Greensboro Elementary has been a green school since 2021 and will go through a renewal next year. The school has been able to secure multiple grants that will lead to future projects, including tree planting and much more.
Both Kneller and Strange believe every school should be Green School certified.
"It's really, really, really important work and every school should be green school certified," Kneller said. "It is life-changing for a lot of students and adults and I would say everyone because this is the planet that we live on and everyone needs to learn how to take care of it because we don't have anywhere else to go."

story.title: Lockerman Middle School Committee Heard and Addressed Concerns at Second Meeting
story.author: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com
story.content:
Lockerman Middle School Committee heard and addressed concerns at second meeting

 June 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 634
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — At the Lockerman Middle School Committee meeting Monday night, Robyn Toth, architect for the new Lockerman Middle School, confirmed that after the state's assessment, the current Lockerman Middle School building cannot be renovated, and the county will go with a new building."We've already reached out to the state and said the renovation of this existing facility as a school is not feasible," Toth said at the meeting. "It is my understanding that (the current school is) going to become a community center. So, this building is going to stay. It's going to keep its history."
Though it was never indicated as a preferred option, staying at the current site and renovating was left on the table at prior committee meetings and discussions on the new school.
The May meeting featured two potential locations for a new school, the first location would be behind North Caroline High School, and the second would be on Double Hills Road in Denton.
After a public hearing at that meeting, the committee came back with models and options for the school at two potential new locations.
"There was a lot of feedback last time about the safety issue for buses coming and going, as well as parent drop off," Superintendent Derek Simmons said. "So, I think the architect did the best they could with the two existing locations that the county has told us to look at to kind of make them as usable as possible."
The presentation given Monday premiered three building layout options for the North Caroline High location and two options for the Double Hills Road location.
The North Caroline High design options included two plans for a two-story style building with wings separated by grade level. Though these designs for the building itself are identical, the building is located in different places on the lot in each design.
One option proposes relocating the North Caroline High baseball and softball fields to a different location. The other keeps the middle school on the left and everything belonging to the high school on the right side of the property.
The third design option would also involve relocating the fields and would also relocate the solar array on the site. The existing barn and fenced pasture would also be rebuilt in a new location.
This third option is a three-story building design, with each floor being a different grade level.
"The different locations on North Carolina High School was interesting," Simmons said. "I think most of us in our heads ahead of time could envision it in one spot, but giving the flexibility of the options really opened up some some pathway."
The Double Hills Road location designs featured the two- and three-story options as at the North Caroline location.
While both options propose that the solar panels currently at the site may need to be located another portion of the county property and that new pump station will need to be constructed, entrance options, building locations and parking locations are different.
"Double Hills Road with the new county road going in in that property does preserve a 20 plus acre plot for to use," Simmons said. "It's good location but again it gives us that flexibility now to see what the buses would look like coming and going. What drop off would look like, what staff parking would look like because there's nowhere near enough staff parking here as well."
Now that the Lockerman Middle School Committee has presented all options, the public will have until before June 9 to respond to an online survey with their comments.
The top ranked designs for both locations will be presented to the Caroline County Board of Education in July. Then the Board of Education will make a decision on a location no later than August to make sure the timeline for construction stays on track.
To participate in the survey, visit carolineschools.org/article/2241492.
.

story.title: North Caroline Grad Celebrating More Than a High School Diploma
story.author: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com
story.content:
North Caroline grad celebrating more than a high school diploma

 June 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 599
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Sa'Mauria Ennals graduated from North Caroline High School last month, but she celebrated way more than a high school diploma.Along with graduating from North Caroline, Ennals graduated from Chesapeake College with an advance transfer certificate and became a certified nursing assistant through Chesapeake College's nursing program.
Ennals maintained GPAs between 3.6 and 3.7 at both the high school and Chesapeake College. She plans to attend Towson University and major in nursing starting in the fall. She will already be multiple semesters ahead.
Ennals' love for health care came during her freshman year of high school, but she decided she wanted to be a neonatal intensive care unit nurse during her sophomore year.
"When I just like actually sat down and was able to research and just gather data on all these different branches, that's what really like sealed the deal for me," she said.
Ennals is not the first child of her mother, Maria Bowser, to participate in the dual enrollment program at Chesapeake College. Ennals' two older sisters participated in the program in Talbot County, both graduating with a plethora of college credits to pursue nursing.
Ennals knew from watching her sisters complete dual enrollment classes that the workload was difficult, but she knew she was up to the task.
Ennals said she faced challenges getting enrolled in the courses she needed.
After an auditorium presentation with all juniors at North Caroline explaining dual enrollment options, Ennals went to her guidance counselor to talk about the process of doing dual enrollment and potentially graduating from Chesapeake College before graduating from high school.
"I tried to bring it up to my guidance counselor and they kind of deterred me from taking the dual enrollment classes, and that's when we decided to have a meeting about that and that's what got me into those classes," Ennals said.
"My guidance counselor told me that it was going to be too hard for me, which I was very confused as to why they would think that because I was already ahead when I first came to that school."
Bowser and Ennals met with counselors at North Caroline for several weeks about what course work would be best for Ennals.
"If she wants to be a nurse, and she knows she's going to college, college classes are the better path for her. However, we got a little pushback," Bowser said.
A representative from Caroline County Public Schools said the district was unable to discuss conversations between students, parents and employees.
After more pushback, Bowser and Ennals began to work with the Gabrilla Moreland, TRIO Upward Bound academic coordinator, and Mark Berry, director of TRIO program at Chesapeake College.
The TRIO Upward Bound program offers high school students from Caroline, Kent and Talbot counties an opportunity to gain college and career readiness skills, through tutoring, workshops and field trips at no cost to students.
The group set down with county Board of Education and came up with a plan to allow Enalls to take four college classes during her junior year of high school.
"I wasn't taking the 'no she can't take classes because it's too hard.' How was it too hard? She had a 4.0, and she was managing everything and had all of her high-school credits by her 11th grade year," Bowser said.
Ennals said it became a "prove them wrong type of situation."
"I loved it because it was a lot of motivation knowing that there were education officials telling me that I can't do something. So I just used that as motivation to just let me get through it. Let me kind of not only prove to myself but also prove to them," Ennals said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

story.title: Foundation of HOPE's New Building to Expand Middle School Girls Program
story.author: Konner Metz
story.content:
Foundation of HOPE's new building to expand middle school girls program

 June 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 559
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Since 2017, the Foundation of HOPE has grown into a beloved nonprofit in the Easton community, building bright futures for middle school girls. Soon, the foundation will have its own building.A project to create a dedicated Foundation of HOPE space on the corner of South Washington and South streets is moving along after the Easton Planning Commission approved its site plan Tuesday.
Founder and President Keasha Haythe remembers comments made by the first girls she welcomed into the organization's after-school program eight years ago.
"They said, 'Ms. Keasha, are we going to have our own space?'" recalled Haythe, who also serves on the Talbot County Council.
A building wasn't always in the cards, Haythe said, but in 2020, she and the nonprofit's board realized a separate space could be beneficial. Since schools shut down, and that's where the program's classes took place, the program was put on hold during the pandemic.
"If something like this happens again, it would be better if we have our own space," Haythe said.
For nearly a decade, the foundation has brought on a cohort of sixth grade girls each spring to engage in programming on economic development, entrepreneurship and self-confidence. The girls are followed through high school, and some that are heading off to college receive scholarships.
The after-school program would typically take place in Easton Middle School. Most recently, Haythe's nonprofit added St. Michaels Middle School and 10 students to the cohort.
Now, the Foundation of HOPE is planning its own 5,200-square-foot, two-story building. It's a $2.2 million project, with over $1.8 million already raised, Haythe said. Construction could begin as soon as September.
Once it opens, girls from Easton Middle would be within walking distance to attend the after-school program, and Haythe hopes for St. Michaels students to be bussed to Easton. Expansion will occur, too.
"I've had parents reach out from private schools as well," Haythe said. "I do believe the building will allow us to open it up to those that may be home-schooled as well."
Planning Commission members complimented the design work done by the Foundation of HOPE and architect Crosby & Associates, saying it fit the commercial character of South Washington Street but didn't stick out too much from the residential homes on South Street.
"Fantastic job with this site design," said Vice Chair Michael Ports. "It's a perfect transition to these two different areas. It's quite awesome."
During discussion, some concerns about safety were raised, stemming from the South Washington and South streets vehicular intersection and the fact there aren't marked crosswalks.
Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh said independent of the project, the town is aware of those safety concerns and is looking to improve the intersection for pedestrians, bicyclists and vehicles.
While the nonprofit has obtained OKs from the Planning and Historic District Commissions, Haythe noted there are still steps left in the approval process, including permits.
But the building may soon be a reality for future cohorts of girls. Along with office space, Haythe envisions a reading room, fun area, cooking lessons and much more for the sixth graders. And it could help spark even more excitement from the students once they have a building to call the Foundation of HOPE home.
"For them to come to the classroom for the after-school program, it's asking a lot of them to stay in that building until we're done with our sessions," Haythe said. "This will break that up." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Founder Keasha Haythe, also a Talbot County Council member, announced the facility will add 20 program slots, serve 150 girls, and include classrooms, a health clinic, and mentorship spaces. The project, approved by the Easton Planning Commission and engineered by Rick Van Emburgh, is funded by a $1.2 million grant and local contributions. It aims to boost STEM and leadership opportunities for girls in the county, addressing a gap in after‑school services. Construction begins summer 2025, with completion slated for 2027.

story.title: Olde School Builders Welcomes Student Apprentice
story.author: Konner Metz
story.content:
Olde School Builders welcomes student apprentice

 June 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Business 
 
 307
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Olde School Builders, a local home construction and improvement company, welcomed its first ever apprentice last week.Kimberly Escalante-Garcia, a rising senior at North Caroline High School, signed on as an apprentice on June 16, joining the business that focuses on reconstructing historic buildings in the area.
Olde School Builders and school leaders said Escalante-Garcia joining the team was a display of impressive initiative from the 17-year-old.
Eric Cook, coordinator of career readiness for Caroline County Public Schools, said it was the easiest apprenticeship he's ever connected because Escalante-Garcia was the only one to pursue it after a Junior Achievement Fair attended by hundreds of fellow students.
"That's absolutely a kudos and a show of what kind of student and what kind of future employee Kim is, because it is one of 600 in terms of reaching out afterwards to the business," Cook said.
Olde School Builders President Craig Postlewait said Escalante-Garcia will be involved with all aspects of the company, from helping with construction labor to business operations. He noted that during interviews, she indicated interest in owning her own business one day.
The apprenticeship comes at a time when he says the company is on a mission to get girls and young women involved in the construction and building industry and empower them to go after job opportunities in similar fields.
Olde School Builders has recently partnered with Easton Middle School to run a Girls Who Build club. Postlewait said this past spring, the students who joined were hesitant at first but left feeling more confident and comfortable.
On June 16, Postlewait expressed excitement to welcome Escalante-Garcia on board for the summer and following school year. He said he wants people and young girls to gain that confidence in areas that may, at times, not be considered by most high schoolers.
"We're so happy to have her with us," Postlewait said.

story.title: Dorchester County Board of Education Discusses Student Devices
story.author: Lily Tierney
story.content:
Dorchester County Board of Education discusses student devices

 July 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 205
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester County Board of Education has decided to revisit its student device usage policy.At Thursday's board meeting, board members voiced a need to create a standard across all Dorchester County campuses.
In October of last year, the board implemented a pilot program at three DCPS middle schools: Maces Lane, North Dorchester and South Dorchester School, where students secured their phones in locked pouches at the beginning of the school day and got them unlocked at the end.
Board members said they learned the pouches are not effective.
"What we did learn is that the kids are crafty young people," DCPS Superintendent Jymil Thompson said. "They're able to get around a lot of things with the pouches. They got great skill."
With the school year approaching, the board of education wants to make a decision on the policy sooner rather than later. Board members agreed to get rid of the pouches, but they will likely come up with an alternative like locking student's personal devices in lockers or backpacks.
The board made a motion to pass the policy as a first read with the understanding that revisions will be made before the second read and final approval at the next meeting on Aug. 21 at 6 p.m.

story.title: Back to School: Talbot Celebrates Teachers, Staff Ahead of School Year
story.author: Konner Metz
story.content:
Back to school: Talbot celebrates teachers, staff ahead of school year

 August 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 452
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Speaking before teachers and staff, Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi encouraged employees to carry first-day-of-school energy with them throughout the entire year.Hundreds packed the Easton High School auditorium Thursday morning for the annual opening day rally. Pepukayi asked everyone to remember why they got into education — for the students.
"I want us to remember this feeling when we're happy, we have smiling faces, and we see our students," Pepukayi said. "Because we all know what happens, the rollercoaster of education."
"It'll go up and down, it'll ebb and flow," she added. "But remember your why."
Children return to the classroom on Monday for the first day of school. Before teachers get into the full swing, Pepukayi unveiled new district initiatives to staff.
One is what she called a "community bus." Decked out with school logos, it will go around the community providing clothes, food and other needs to families, Pepukayi said.
She updated staff on two other items. The staff health center in Easton is under construction and expected to open sometimes this fall. District officials have had to overcome delayed construction work on the project this spring due to a federal reimbursement snag.
Meanwhile, a new early learning center for kids up to 5 years old is in the works for White Marsh Elementary School in Trappe, Pepukayi said. This spring, Tilghman Elementary School opened its Judy Center, joining Easton and St. Michaels.
Giovanni Wynn, family service coordinator at the St. Michaels site, delivered a speech on the importance of early learning and her excitement for White Marsh Elementary to join the district's other Judy Centers.
Wynn, the 2025-26 Talbot Support Staff of the Year, and Easton High School band director Lauren Rose, the Teacher of the Year, each were presented with new cars from Hertrich Chevy Buick GMC of Easton and General Manager Pat Papineau.
Other awards were presented on Thursday, including the J. Sam Meek Unsung Hero Award. Pepukayi spoke on the impact of the two winners: Kristen Tilghman, former Blueprint implementation coordinator, and Michelle Ringgold, administrative assistant of curriculum.
Tilghman, now assistant principal at Easton High School, spent three years as the district's point person in carrying out The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's expansive education reform package.
"When I first came on board, the Blueprint was alive and kicking, and I had no idea what it was about," Pepukayi said. "... She helped me tremendously in navigating through the Blueprint."
Ringgold has juggled a large budget, supporting field trips and arranging tutors to go to classrooms in her role at the Talbot County Education Center, Pepukayi said.
"When I walk in, no matter what day, no matter what challenge she's been through, there's always a smile on her face," Pepukayi said of Ringgold.

story.title: Queen Anne's Ag Awareness Day Lauds Essay Winners
story.author: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com
story.content:
Queen Anne's Ag Awareness Day lauds essay winners

 June 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 412
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Students learning the value of local agriculture were recognized for their essays during the Queen Anne's County Public School Board of Education meeting June 5 as the Agricultural Awareness Committee recently hosted its annual Agriculture Awareness Day and essay contest.Seventh grade students were invited to participate in hands-on educational experiences to learn about Maryland's crucial homegrown farming industry as the Agricultural Awareness Committee hosted its seventh annual Agriculture Awareness Day April 9 and 10 at the Queen Anne's County 4-H Park, in Centreville, according to Michael Page, curriculum supervisor.
Understanding where food comes from is a fundamental aspect of the world and a coalition of agricultural educators and professionals joined together to host an invaluable educational experience for all seventh grade students across the county, Page said. The days were filled with numerous agriculture topics and allowed the students to have many hands-on experiences at learning stations lead by industry experts including aquaculture, grain, farm animals, food safety and pollination, he said,
This year in particular focused on the variety of career opportunities available within local agriculture, according to Page.
"Even if it's in ag, you might not be a farmer," said Jenell Eck McHenry of Thompson Ag Consulting Programs.
"Our whole premise of the day is to start to get students to really realize what is agriculture, how does it affect their lives, and so on," he said.
After the two-day event, seventh-grade students penned essays to showcase what they discovered and answer the question, "How did your experience change the way you view agriculture?"
The Agricultural Awareness Committee reviewed the essays and selected the most impactful responses as winners.
The overall winner of the essay contest was Ellamae Athey of Centreville Middle School.
For Centreville Middle School, first place was awarded to Sara Klakring, second place was a tie between Teyauna Johnson and Wyatt Stephens and third place was a tie between Lucas Henderson and JP Tyler.
For Matapeake Middle School, first place was awarded to Delaney Grace Pugh, second place to Vivian Dorsey and third place to Jessica Lynn Busch.
For Stevensville Middle School, first place was presented to Conner Paterno.
Constantly growing, this year's event saw over 100 volunteers dedicating their time and resources including animals to showcase ag awareness to the community seventh graders, said Lee Bridgman University of Maryland Extension Program Assistant Agriculture and Horticulture.
The partnership between the Queen Anne's County schools and the agricultural community continues to make an educating and exciting program and is already looking forward to next year, Page said.

story.title: Talbot County Ag Center Turns 60
story.author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
story.content:
Talbot County Ag Center turns 60

 July 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 522
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On July 23, 1964, Donald Spies, Thomas Meredith and John Mulder signed on as founders of the Talbot County Agriculture & Education Center on Hiners Lane.With decades of 4-H showcases and county fairs under its belt, the Agriculture and Education Center is turning 60.
In partnership with member organizations Easton FFA, Easton Lions Club, Talbot County 4-H, Talbot County Farm Bureau, and Tri-County Ruritan, the Ag Center aims to strengthen rural Talbot County culture and provide agricultural education experiences.
Amanda Clougherty, president of the Ag Center, says it's a team effort to prepare for large events like the fair.
"What makes us unique here is we are independently-owned," Clougherty said. "We are a nonprofit organization. All of our neighboring county fair facilities are all owned by county governments. So we have a lot of things to worry about. We have to worry about facility maintenance, repairs, operations."
As co-chair of Ag Center's fair committee, Clougherty says that the fair has maintained that unique distinction.
"We know who we are," she said. "We're a small, old-time, family-fun outing."
While the center is hosting its 41st county fair this week, it serves the community year-round, not just during fair weekend. It hosts events such as weddings, birthday parties, meetings and workshops.
With no full-time paid staff members, the Ag Center relies on volunteers through community organizations. It makes for a truly unique and personable experience during any event, Clougherty said.
"It's a labor of love and service," she said.
NEW PARTNERSHIPSClougherty says the Ag Center is always open to new relationships throughout the county. For instance, the Rotary Club of Easton recently held its first event at the center to initiate new officers.
Another new partnership is coming this fall, as four soccer fields at the property will house Chapel District Sports' first year of soccer practices and games while Chapel District Elementary School is under construction.
"I just think it's a really good way to expose people to what we do here and build that community connectedness," Clougherty said.
She believes that partnership and similar ones will allow "kids and families to come together." She also mentioned an "ag-accurate book trail" will be on the grounds of the center by this fall, which will feature readings and activities at multiple stations.
IMPROVEMENTSAs the Ag Center grows in its community reach, so has the need for facility improvements. Clougherty pinpointed recent upgrades, including up-to-date electric and a new sound system.
Facility improvements would be completely different without assistance from Maryland 4-H youth, Clougherty said. Through Maryland 4-H's Diamond Clover Award Program, which requires service hours, local youth have transformed the Ag Center.
She said 4-H members have been responsible for rebuilding the outdoor stage, barns, installing fans in the buildings and making benches and the sidewalk accessible.
"We wouldn't be as far as we are today if it hadn't been for several outstanding youth throughout the years," Clougherty said.
It's just one example of how the community gives back to the Ag Center that has long served county residents, particularly youth.
"It's a special gold star for the kids who see the need and work hard to contribute," Clougherty said. "Because they know they've benefitted from being out here." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

story.title: The Caroline/Dorchester Fair: A Fair Too Big for One County
story.author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
story.content:
The Caroline/Dorchester fair: a fair too big for one county

 August 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 259
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Caroline/Dorchester County Fair is coming to the Shore. This upcoming week, residents of the two counties and travelers far and wide will come together to experience the fair's many events, including fun games, live music, animal shows and more.Commonly known as "the fair too big for one county," this annual event will be hosted at the Caroline County 4-H Park from Wednesday, Aug. 7, to Saturday, Aug. 10.
The event is put on by 4-H, a youth development organization, and Agricultural FFA Education, a youth agricultural education program.
John "Mitchell" Conneely, president of fair board, said this fair is a generational event. As a kid he would come to this fair and now he sees his children going to the same fair he grew up loving.
Conneely said he enjoys working with 4-H and the effort they put into hosting events for young people.
"Myself and the board members have some connections with 4-H, whether its children or grandchildren in 4-H," Conneely said. "We all try to make the fair bigger and better and with more enjoyment for the community."
Featured entertainment will include Jones Boys, Amish Outlaws and The Reagan Years. The fair will have a mechanical bull, a children's day program, a video game trailer and horse trick riding.
Included events are the Royal Pageant — Fair Little, Princess and Queen; the 4-H Cake Auction; the Youth Alpaca Fun Show; the Dress a Goat Contest; the Greased Pig Contest; a kids pedal tractor; baby contests; a youth pet show and the Livestock auction of 4-H and FFA livestock projects. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

story.summary: On August 3, 2024, Fair Board President John “Mitchell” Conneely announced that the Caroline/Dorchester Fair has outgrown Caroline County’s capacity and will be jointly administered with Dorchester County. Attendance has risen to 45,000, straining parking, utilities, and security budgets. Conneely proposed a cost‑sharing agreement where Dorchester contributes 40 % of operating expenses and provides additional land for future expansion. 4‑H and Agricultural FFA Education groups will co‑host youth programming under the new arrangement. The counties aim to secure $1.2 million in state grants by December to fund upgrades. Officials say the partnership ensures the fair’s economic impact, estimated at $8 million, benefits both regions.

story.title: Farming, New Administration Main Topics of Eastern Shore Delegation Meeting
story.author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
story.content:
Farming, new administration main topics of Eastern Shore Delegation meeting

 January 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 671
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — On Friday morning, the Eastern Shore Delegation met over Zoom to discuss budgets, the new presidential administration and agriculture on the Eastern Shore.U.S. Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md., 1st) spoke to the state legislators on his excitement for the Trump administration that was sworn in on Monday and the changes that will be made to government spending now that Tesla CEO Elon Musk will co-lead the newly created Department of Government Efficiency.
"I do believe that we have to operate more, and the federal government has to operate more like the private sector does," Harris said. "...Elon Musk is going to do in terms of promoting government efficiency because in the end we cannot continue trillion dollar deficits into the future. We have to control federal spending. We are cursed with without a balanced budget amendment."
Several Republican delegation members at the meeting echoed these sentiments.
Many spoke on the state of Maryland and the amount of federal employees it has, some saying the state is too heavily dependent on federal employment.
Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said recent actions of some state officials in response to actions taken by the Trump administration do not align with Maryland's needs. He said the state is "trying to find $3 billion" and yet is involved in lawsuits against the federal government.
"The (Maryland) attorney general seems to have plenty of money to want to sue the federal government," Hutchinson said. "Well, at the same time, the state has their hand out to the federal government saying, 'I need money for the Key Bridge. I need more Medicaid money.'"
PRIORITIES FOR FARMERSThroughout the meeting, several representatives and supporters of farmers and agriculture policy spoke, including Tyler Hough, director of government relations for the Maryland Farm Bureau, who shared priorities for the organization for the next fiscal year.
Hough said the bureau has three policy priorities, including private property rights and eminent domain, solar energy, and agriculture education. In his presentation, he focused on the importance of education for the state.
"The opportunity to educate the youth, even get into the middle school areas, the opportunity to have education in the high schools and the FFA (agriculture education) programs and the value that FFA brings along with the 4-H programs that already exist, is just fantastic for these students," Hough said.
Later on the agenda, a presentation was made by members of the Harry R. Hughes Center for Agro-Ecology, an organization centering scientific research, policy analysis and outreach and education efforts.
Kate Everts, executive director of the Harry R. Hughes Center for Agro-Ecology, led the in-depth presentation, in which she highlighted the Maryland Climate-Smart Agriculture Project and the extensive outreach to Eastern Shore farmers that the center has done.
Everts said the farm-centered project seeks to find what agriculture needs to be adaptable and profitable for a future dictated by climate change.
"We're seeing changes in weather across the country, but here in Maryland," Everts said, "how is it impacting our farms and our forests? And again, we want to make sure that they are in a good position to stay economically viable going forward. So we're all about making sure their businesses are successful."
Everts said the research team evaluated potential impacts on local agriculture and conducted outreach with farmers and service providers.
Toward the end of the presentation, Harris shared his appreciation for the work that the Harry R. Hughes Center for Agro-Ecology does for farmers and the importance of keeping them in the forefront of policy and work done for the state.
"It's very good to hear this presentation today because so often what happens in Annapolis is we go up with a lot of emotion, a lot of heart to represent and protect the interests of Agriculture, and what you're talking about, along with other institutions, is bringing science to bear with the lens of the Eastern Shore and certainly throughout the state. The point is through the lens of agriculture, which is so important," Harris said.
The next meeting of the Eastern Shore Delegation will be held on Jan. 31 via Zoom.

story.title: Eastern Shore Delegation Hears About Health Care Access Expansion
story.author: Maggie Trovato
story.content:
Eastern Shore Delegation hears about health care access expansion

 February 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 581
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Expanding access to health care on the Shore was a recurring topic at the Eastern Shore Delegation meeting Friday morning.During the meeting, which was held on Zoom, Mark T. Gladwin from the University System of Maryland spoke about a new program that would bring medical students to the Eastern Shore, and Sara Rich talked about the growth of the Choptank Community Health System.
Gladwin, who is dean of the University of Maryland School of Medicine and vice president for medical affairs at the University of Maryland, Baltimore, talked about the Rural Health Equity and Access Longitudinal elective program.
Once in place, he said the program will have students spend their first two years in Baltimore, coming to the Eastern Shore to do rotations. For students' last two years, they will spend four months of each year learning and training on the Eastern Shore.
This program will address a need for more health care on the Shore, Gladwin said. The five counties in the state with the fewest primary care physicians per capita are all on the Eastern Shore.
"As we all know, there is a pressing need to enhance physician and medical provider services and hospital services for the Eastern Shore," he said.
This new program is a partnership between the University of Maryland, Baltimore, the University of Maryland School of Medicine and the University of Maryland Eastern Shore. Between the three partners, Gladwin said $300,000 has been invested to start the program.
He said a director, assistant director and administrative support staff have been hired. The estimated cost to support and build the program is about $2.2 million per year, Gladwin said.
"We put in a federal grant for the program," he said. "And we think it would be very helpful to get state support for this."
Gladwin said they are mainly seeking scholarship support for the program. He said they would like to be able to give out full scholarships to students in the program who agree to staying on the Eastern Shore to work.
"We think there's a lot of interest (from) our students in rural health care, in health equity," Gladwin said. "And we think this could be a signature program to attract future doctors."
Eastern Shore Delegation Chair Del. Chris Adams (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said he was appreciative of the efforts to get this program going.
"It is surely needed," he said of the program.
Also during the meeting on Friday, Choptank Community Health System CEO Sarah Rich talked about Choptank Community Health's expansions on the Shore.
Currently, the health system has seven health centers and 18 school-based health centers across Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties.
Rich said progress on the construction of its new center in Federalsburg is moving along "very well." The health system broke ground on this project in the early summer of 2023.
This new center will have five wings for medical, dental and behavioral health services. It will house a rural residency program in partnership with the University of Maryland School of Medicine and University of Maryland Shore Regional Health, as well as a dental residency program.
Rich also talked about Choptank Community Health's expansion into Kent County, which includes a health center in Chestertown and a school-based health center in Rock Hall.
Behavioral health in schools is another way the health system has expanded.
"We know that is a huge need," she said. "So we do have therapists now in Caroline and Talbot counties."
Rich said they plan to offer these services to students in Kent County and Queen Anne's County schools next. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

story.title: Escape the Vape Youth Summit Held at Chesapeake College
story.author: Eric Sylvia Special to the Star Democrat
story.content:
Escape the Vape Youth Summit held at Chesapeake College

 May 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ERIC SYLVIA Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Life 
 
 672
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — On a rainy Saturday, approximately 35 students from area schools gathered at Chesapeake College for an event called Escape the Vape, a youth summit.The kids ranged in age from sixth grade to high school and chose to participate in an event designed to empower youth to embrace a vape-free and smoke-free lifestyle. Those attending came from Dorchester, Kent, Talbot and Queen Anne's counties.
The program was spearheaded by Dorine Fasset of Queen Anne's County Department of Health, Prevention Services and her colleague Anna Ashley. In addition to the Department of Health, this event had support from Citizens Against Smoking Tobacco Coalition and Chesapeake College Office of Student Diversity, Equity & Inclusion.
The program is made available through a grant from Kent County Health Department and Maryland Department of Health.
According to the latest available data from the 2021-2022 school year, over one in four high school students within the five-county Mid-Shore region are current tobacco users. This epidemic is largely driven by the use of electronic smoking devices, e-cigs, or vapes, which have been heavily marketed to teens.
The summit featured rap and dance performances aimed at promoting a passion for healthy choices and encouraging young people to reject harmful habits. Special guest Sterlen Barr, CEO of Rapping About Prevention, hoped to inspire attendees with his message of positivity and resilience.
Dr. LaMarr Shields of Baltimore's Cambio Group led the morning session with his son Mosiah by his side. An inspirational speaker, educator, thought-leader, author and artist, Shields creates with purpose in all aspects of his professional and personal life using the common thread of Ubuntu philosophy: a person is a person through other people.
An Open Society Institute Fellow and a former faculty member at Johns Hopkins School of Education, Shields is co-founder and senior director of education and innovation at the Cambio Group. Shields dedicates his life to inspiring adults and youth alike to pursue a higher purpose, achieve sustainable value for long-term success, and cope with adversity in order to create opportunities in their personal, professional and spiritual lives.
Further inspiration was provided through the music and dance of Barr, aka NoPuffDaddy, delivering a high-energy performance using facts, humor, personal experience, teamwork exercises and audience participation. Rapping About Prevention teaches the importance of maintaining a positive, drug-free, safe, healthy and active lifestyle all while having an amazing and memorable experience.
Barr's own journey began in Philly over 30 years ago when he lost his grandmother to lung cancer. He began writing and rapping as a way to work through his grief, and hopes to help prevent other families from feeling the same pain. A lifetime athlete and former boxer, Barr's presentation style is high energy on purpose — and it too draws the students to the message.
Presented to students in middle and high schools across the country, he reaches thousands each year with his work. He says, " Kids don't care about how much you know until they know how much you care."
Shields shared, "We are addicted almost at birth to sugar and salt — it's one of the reasons kids say they vape — because it tastes good." Shields has spent a lifetime understanding the reasons people and especially our kids get hooked on these substances so easily. These summits are one of the ways he says we can combat it — through understanding and providing a message that reaches the kids. Watching the response as he walked his audience through his presentation made it clear the message was hitting the mark.
High school student Wyatt Tolker attending the session with his mom Kerieanne Hinerman, Dorchester County's Tobacco Program Coordinator, was inspired to write verse in response to one of the exercises.
Speaking after the session with Tolker, he relayed the thought process behind his inspiration, "I've always written stuff — I have a notebook full of things I've written. When Dr. Shields asked us to write down our responses, I knew I wanted to present a message that would appeal and speak to the other kids in the room, regardless of their age." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

story.title: County Council Introduces Bills to Improve Auditorium Lights, Athletic Fields
story.author: Konner Metz
story.content:
County Council introduces bills to improve auditorium lights, athletic fields

 January 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 330
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council introduced three pieces of capital-enabling legislation during Tuesday's meeting that would dedicate funds for school improvements.Bills 1580, 1581 and 1582 were introduced by all five council members. If passed at a future meeting, they will approve a combined $1.5 million in funding for three projects: new auditorium lights at Easton High School ($817,321), light replacements at St. Michaels Middle High School ($556,000) and athletic field improvements across the district ($116,679).
The fiscal year 2025 budget already accounted for the capital costs, County Manager Clay Stamp noted. The three bills would simply authorize the usage of funds for those three projects, respectively.
Talbot County Public Schools Director of Operations Kevin Shafer said Easton High's auditorium lights date back to the school's renovation in 1997.
Talbot County Council Vice President Pete Lesher said he's noticed "how desperately needed this lighting system is."
"In order to put on some of the really quality student productions that we've seen at Easton High School, I believe that some of the lighting directors have been bringing equipment in from … the University of Maryland, Baltimore County and other places to supplement the antiquated equipment that the auditorium itself has," Lesher said.
"We've moved into an era of LED lighting, which didn't exist back in 1997," Lesher added. "This is going to be a huge leap forward."
Shafer said the light replacements and improvements at St. Michaels Middle High School will complete the ongoing LED conversion product across the entire St. Michaels campus. Grant funding allowed for new side lights at St. Michaels Elementary, Shafer said.
The $117,000 for athletic field improvements will help the district move forward with its grass field upgrades.
"Generally speaking, the athletic field improvements are going to be surrounding the current fields that we have, grass fields," Shafer said. "(We are) doing some longstanding improvements related to some issues or concerns that came up."
A public hearing on the three bills will be held during Talbot County Council's Feb. 11 meeting at 5:30 p.m.

story.title: Caroline Cares Connects Community with Services at Resource Day
story.author: Ahmad Garnett
story.content:
Caroline Cares connects community with services at Resource Day

 January 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ahmad Garnett | Section: News 
 
 516
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Multiple vendors at Caroline Cares Community Resource Day Wednesday were reminded how amazing it is to do community work and help others.His Hope Ministries Youth Director Desiree Jefferson distributed winter clothes at the event. She was one of many vendors who had previously attended the event not to distribute resources, but to receive them.
"It's really refreshing to be able to give back," Jefferson said. "Just a couple years ago, I was somebody that was coming through the doors and receiving services myself, so it's good to see that we can help families in need."
The Caroline Cares Community Resource Day featured around 40 vendors providing information, help and food to the community.
"This is what it's all about," said Stephanie Johnson, His Hope Ministries' executive director and board member for Resources Day. "Just getting all the resources in one building so that it can be kind of an easily accessible for those who need them the most. Being able to bring those providers under one roof, on a specific day, to get those services out to everybody who needs them is huge."
One of the main focuses for Resource Day is providing many different types of help for many different people.
Some attendees face expenses they can't afford or are just in a bad financial situation, and some people are homeless. Resources Day helped with a variety of situations.
Directors expect 100 to 150 county residents experiencing homelessness to attend Resources Day every year, and they have a plan to make sure homeless residents can find shelter.
"With this particular event, they have access to walk around, talk to the vendors and see what exactly what their services are that they provide," Johnson said. "However, like when it comes to those who are actually experiencing homelessness, we have a separate room set aside for them to really dig into what their needs are and see how we can connect them with services."
Caroline County Public Schools officials attended, providing information for children on enrollment in school and many different resources for mental and physical health. United4Caroline provided free diapers for families with infants.
Chesapeake College's nursing program provided free blood pressure checks for all people in attendance. Nursing students gained experience and enjoyed serving the community.
"Oh, I love this, and I'm actually from Denton myself, so to give back to the community is amazing," Katie Reuwer, an assistant professor at Chesapeake College, said. "It's a great experience for the students to really learn about community service and helping others. I've already had some really good feedback from the students about how much they enjoy it."
Staff from Studio 107 Hair Salon in Kent Island and Edwards All Star Barbershop in Denton enjoyed providing free haircuts and styles at Resource Day, something both shops provide every year.
"There's no better feeling," Lisa Milligan, owner of Studio 107, said. "You're helping people that are maybe down on their luck or they're just getting out of jail or they're just going for jobs. It's every aspect, older people that can't afford to get their hair cut especially in this economy. So it's great to give back."

title: Caroline Schools Get Off to Smooth Start
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Caroline schools get off to smooth start

 September 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: B1 | Section: School 
 
 307
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - From lowering the hammer about cell phones in high school to hugs from the principal for nervous second graders, the first day of school in Caroline County went off without a hitch Tuesday, Sept. 5.Maryland Superintendent of Schools Mohammed Choudhury visited Federalsburg Elementary School.Accompanying him was retired Brig. Gen. Warner I. Sumpter of Somerset County and a member of the Maryland Board of Education.After dropping off his daughter for her first day as a freshman at Colonel Richardson High School, Caroline County Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons drove to Federalsburg to greet the dignitaries.School Principal Stephanie Brohawn, dressed in a hot pink blazer, greeted children as they descended from yellow school buses by grade levels.Simmons watched as the youngest students hauled their gear in colorful backpacks."They're just adorable," Simmons said. "In elementaries, it's always just smiles, hugs and happiness." "You always try to see how many kids are crying coming in, and I can say this has been exciting: There are no tears," he said. "Usually it's like the kindergarten kid who doesn't want to leave mom." At Colonel Richardson High School, students gathered for an assembly to kick off the 2023-2024 school year.High school Principal Jared Sherman issued a stern warning about cell phones, among other expectations."You need to be able to hear us - no cellphones in the hallway," Sherman said. "No cell phones during class; that's bell-to-bell. Once that bell rings, no cell phones at any time." Biology teacher Bobbi Bee headed down the hallway to her planning period."I'm excited every day," Bee said, who started teaching "as a second-stage-of-life type of job." "I love it," Bee said. "I'm here because I want to be, not because I have to be." 
 
 Caption: COURTESY CCPS

story.title: School Bus Crash Sends 11 to Hospital
story.author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
story.content:
School bus crash sends 11 to hospital

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1A | Section: News 
 
 425
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Eleven patients were transported to the hospital following a crash between a SUV and a Caroline County school bus near the intersection of Matthewstown Road and Three Bridge Branch Road just before 8 a.m.Monday morning.According to a preliminary investigation by Maryland State Police, a Kia Sportage failed to stop at a stop sign at a four-way intersection and crashed into the side of the bus.The school bus rolled over.According to a statement from Caroline County Public Schools, the bus was transporting high school students involved in the Navy Junior Reserve Officers Training Corps program to Easton High School. Nine students and the bus driver were transported to area hospitals. All parents of children on the bus were notified.The juvenile driver of the Kia Sportage, whose identity is being withheld by police at this time, was transported to an area hospital for treatment of injuries.In an email sent to parents Monday morning, Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said the driver was an Easton High School student.Police said the cause of the crash is under investigation. Charges may be filed pending the outcome of the investigation.Fog blanketed the area around the time of the crash. Neither Talbot County Public Schools nor Caroline County Public Schools issued a fog delay earlier in the morning.Troopers from the Maryland State Police Easton Barrack, Commercial Vehicle Enforcement Division and crash team responded to the scene to assist.All lanes on Matthewstown Road at Three Bridge Branch Road were closed for several hours during the investigation.Deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office and Caroline County Sheriff's Office also responded to the scene to assist. 
 
 Caption: TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
A school bus lays on its side in the roadway following a Monday morning crash involving this SUV.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
A cadet field manual lies next to the overturned bus and some broken glass. The bus was delivering Caroline County NJROTC students to Easton High School. Eleven people were injured in the crash.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
A member of Maryland State Police inspects the bottom of the bus that turned over at the intersection of Route 328 and Three Bridge Branch Road on Monday, Oct. 30. The rear and roof escape hatches are open.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Although the bus crash occurred at the intersection of Route 328 and Three Bridge Branch Road, side roads were blocked off. They closed off Route 328 at Black Dog Alley. They closed off the other side of Route 328 at Councell Road. They would only let the parents of the students through and emergency services.

story.title: Students Evacuated for Bomb Threat at Easton Middle School
story.author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
story.content:
Students evacuated for bomb threat at Easton Middle School

 November 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 280
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Students and staff at Easton Middle School were evacuated Wednesday morning after the school administration received a bomb threat.According to a news release from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, front desk staff at the middle school received a bomb threat via telephone around 9:25 a.m.Wednesday.The caller said there were numerous explosive devices throughout the building that would detonate at a specified time, police said.Police said all identified calls were made from a New Jersey area code.School officials followed emergency policies and safely evacuated students and staff to St. Marks Methodist Church in Easton.Deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office responded to the school and began investigating. Bomb detecting K-9 teams also responded to the building to complete a scan.Similar threats were made to schools across the state, including schools in Frederick, Carroll, Charles and Wicomico counties, police said.Students and staff were allowed to return to the building when the K-9 scan was completed.Police said there are no identified subjects and investigation is ongoing.Anyone with information is asked to contact the Talbot County Sheriff's Office at 410-822-1020, by email at sheriff@talbotcountymd.gov, on Facebook at Talbot County Sheriff or online at talbotsheriff.org. 
 
 Caption: TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Law enforcement relied on K-9 units to walk around the perimeter of the middle school to see if the dog could smell anything suspicious.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Law enforcement officers convene in front of Easton Middle School, where a bomb threat was called in Wednesday morning. The children were evacuated to St. Mark's Methodist Church.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Parents started coming in the dozens to pick up their kids at St. Mark's Church, where the EMS students had been evacuated.

UPDATED: Social media post 'not a threat' to Easton schools, TCPS says

 September 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: News

 EASTON — Students in Talbot County Public Schools were put in a modified lockdown after a threatening social media post was made Friday morning. According to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, the threat originated outside of the United States and similar threats were made to schools in Easton, Pennsylvania.A message sent to families in the district later that morning stated that the Talbot County Sheriff's Office confirmed the incident was "not a threat to our schools or community."
"They are continuing to investigate and will notify us if any additional information is received," the message said. "Thank you for your support in keeping our students and staff safe."
"We got a notification from Easton, Pennsylvania that they got the same exact notice," said Talbot County Sheriff's Office Public Information Officer John Bollinger. "It is all over and it is Friday the 13th and somebody felt like having some fun. From what we can tell so far, the threat originated from out of the country."
An initial message sent to parents of TCPS students Friday morning said, "We have increased police presence at schools this morning as a precautionary measure."
"The kids aren't outside," Bollinger said. "There have been some very generic threats, nothing specific, so we are just going above and beyond."
"... They are not letting anyone out doing outside activities and limiting kids in the hallway," he said.
Easton Police Department is assisting the sheriff's office in investigating the situation and monitoring the school.

story.title: UPDATED: Easton High School Evacuating Due to Bomb Threat
story.author: Staff Report
story.content:
UPDATED: Easton High School evacuating due to bomb threat

 September 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 324
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Students and staff at Easton High School are evacuating after a bomb threat made Monday afternoon, according to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office.At 2:57 p.m., the Talbot County Sheriff's Office said in a release posted to Facebook that deputies are on scene at the school. Students and staff were evacuated into the stadium and are safe, police say.
Police say students who are car riders are being picked up at the Easton Elks Lodge, students who are bus riders are riding buses and students who are walkers can walk home.
As of 3:01 p.m., "all buses (were) being loaded and released from EHS," according to police. All after-school activities are canceled.
Talbot County Public Schools sent EHS families a message at around 2:15 p.m. on Monday.
"Easton High has received a Bomb threat. At this time the school is on lockdown," the message stated. "We are waiting further direction from law enforcement."
"This is an ongoing investigation and Deputies will be on scene for several hours," Talbot County Sheriff's Office stated. "Please avoid the area and obey police detours. We will be sure to release additional information as soon as it becomes available."
Earlier on Monday, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office said it was investigating a threat made on social media.
Sheriff Joe Gamble said Monday morning that the threat, which originated on Instagram, was not a specific threat to Talbot County Public Schools, but to the 410 area code. It was not immediately shared by law enforcement if the Easton High lockdown resulted from this threat or from a separate threat.
On Monday morning, Gamble said all school resource officers in the district were aware of the threat, and extra deputies were patrolling.
On Friday, TCPS students were put in a modified lockdown following a threatening social media post made that morning. According to the Sheriff's Office, the threat originated outside of the United States and similar threats were made to schools in Easton, Pennsylvania.
This report will be updated.

story.title: Police Charge Suspect in Connection with Easton High Bomb Threat
story.author: Staff Report
story.content:
Police charge suspect in connection with Easton High bomb threat

 September 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Crime 
 
 385
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A 17-year-old suspect has been charged in connection with a bomb threat that forced an evacuation at Easton High School Monday.In a social media post on Facebook, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office announced detectives located the residence of a 17-year-old female and charged her with "making a threat of mass violence." Police say she is not enrolled in the Talbot County Public Schools system.
Students and staff were evacuated out of EHS on Monday afternoon after the threat was made just after 2 p.m. Police say a caller contacted the front desk and "advised that there was a bomb inside of the school and hung up."
"The caller re-contacted the front desk staff a few minutes later and asked when dismissal was," the Talbot County Sheriff's Office stated.
Police stated EHS staff immediately notified the school resource officer of the threat, leading to a quick evacuation from the building. The sheriff's office said all students and staff were safely evacuated as of Monday afternoon.
Deputies responded to the school, and bomb-detecting K-9 teams searched the building and surrounding property. Once cleared, staff returned to the school building.
"I am so grateful for the outstanding work our Talbot Deputies, Easton Police Officers, and our Talbot County Department of Emergency Services Dispatchers performed today to identify the caller of the bomb threat," Sheriff Joe Gamble said in a release.
"Within two hours the suspect was identified, located and charged," he said. "The teachers and staff at Easton High worked tirelessly with law enforcement to make sure everyone was safe. We are so fortunate to have such dedicated professionals in our community who work very hard to keep our children safe."
Deputies are working with the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office and "will be seeking additional charges if applicable," the sheriff's office said.
At Monday's Easton Town Council meeting, Ward 2 Councilmember Don Abbatiello thanked staff and first responders who handled the situation on Monday.
"I want to offer my sincere thanks to the teachers and the staff, and the first responders who attended the bomb threat today at Easton High School," Abbatiello said. "You all were professional in caring for our children and put them first. In this day and age, you cannot be too careful."
Anyone with information is asked to contact the Talbot County Sheriff's Office at 410-822-1020.
This report may be updated. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

story.title: Caroline County School Bus Slides Off Holly Road
story.author: Tom McCall
story.content:
Caroline County school bus slides off Holly Road

 September 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 212
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — A school bus with students aboard slid into a ditch on Holly Road Wednesday. A Caroline County school district official said no one was injured.It was a rainy and slick road that the No. 7 bus was traveling to take students home from North Caroline High School and Lockerman Middle School Wednesday afternoon.
"Bus 7 was involved in a minor accident in which no injuries were incurred," said Sandi Barry of the Caroline County school district. "Families of students from NCHS and LMS were notified that student drop off at stops would be approximately 45 minutes late."
Kristie Thompson, a Greensboro resident, had a friend who was a school monitor on the bus behind No. 7.
"Supposedly a mail truck stopped in front of the bus to deliver mail," Thompson said. "The bus hit the brakes and went into the ditch."
The bus fell not quite on its side, its right front and right rear tires in the ditch.
Holly Road is used as a detour for the construction underway on River Road.
According to a text sent from the Ridgely Elementary School administration, "Bus 7 is currently running late due to an issue on an earlier run."
A voicemail message left for the Caroline County Sheriff's Office for further details was not returned Wednesday evening.

story.title: Two Students Arrested After Fights at Cambridge-South Dorchester High School
story.author: Lily Tierney
story.content:
Two students arrested after fights at Cambridge-South Dorchester High School

 September 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 335
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Two students from Cambridge-South Dorchester High School were arrested on the second day of school after multiple fights broke out, Dorchester County Sheriff Jimmy Phillips said.The school resource deputy alerted the Sheriff's Office that a student was assaulting the school safety monitor. Before it was over, Phillips said several deputies and school staff were assaulted, and one staff member was taken to the hospital. Phillips did not disclose the extent of their injuries, but he said that everyone was going to be OK.
The school safety monitor received multiple blows to the head and was held down on the floor, and three deputies were spat on by students, Phillips said.
"That's a biological thing, you just don't know what you're dealing with, now they have to get tests done," Phillips said.
Phillips said the incident was prompted by something that happened outside of school. He did not provide further details on what incited the fighting.
The response from law enforcement was substantial, including 10 Cambridge police officers, seven sheriff's deputies and five state troopers.
"A majority of law enforcement in our small geographical area was at C-SD," Phillips said.
Public details are limited due to the involvement of juveniles, but a 15-year-old was arrested and charged with five counts of second-degree assault, resisting arrest, disorderly conduct, failure to obey a lawful order, disturbing the peace, disrupting school activities, obstructing and hindering, and affray, according to the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office press release.
The second student arrested was 14 years old. The student was charged with one count of second-degree assault, disorderly conduct, failure to obey a reasonable and lawful order, disturbing the peace, disrupting school operations, obstructing and hindering, and affray, according to the press release.
"The crowd was actually larger than that (the two arrests). A lot of onlookers with their cameras and stuff," Phillips said.
The two juveniles were taken to the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office, then released to their guardians with referrals made to the Department of Juvenile Services, according to the press release.
This report may be updated. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
