story.title: Woman Charged for Graffiti Acts at Sts. Peter and Paul Elementary
story.author: Konner Metz
story.content:
Woman charged for graffiti acts at Sts. Peter and Paul Elementary

 September 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 719
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A woman is being held at the Talbot County Detention Center after being accused of spray-painting graffiti around town, including at Sts. Peter and Paul Elementary School.Sian Radaskiewicz-King, 32, was arrested Friday by Easton police on charges of malicious destruction of property and use of a hate symbol. She was later charged with defacing religious property and disturbing school operations, among other counts.
According to court documents, King allegedly spray-painted the transgender symbol on dumpsters, the sidewalk and a step outside the Catholic school off of Route 50. Other spray-painted symbols were found on a fence at the Hampton Inn next to the school, per court records.
The symbols were found elsewhere in town, including outside East End Liquors, The Market at Dover Station and other businesses. The transgender symbol, often used to encourage gender inclusivity, is a combination of the male and female signs.
At an unusually crowded bail hearing on Monday afternoon, Talbot County District Court Judge Karen Ketterman ordered King to be held without bond in the Detention Center. A trial is scheduled for Oct. 28.
Many parents and school officials from Sts. Peter and Paul filled the courtroom. School Board Chair Peggy Wilson asked Ketterman to not approve King's release. Wilson cited the Aug. 27 shooting at Annunciation Catholic School in Minneapolis, which killed two children and injured 18 people, as a reason why the school community is concerned for the safety of students.
"Our fear is not the symbol itself, but the possibility of a copycat situation," Wilson said.
King, according to public legal representation, is transgender. She previously attended Sts. Peter and Paul School.
The Minneapolis shooter, Robin Westman, was referred to as transgender by federal officials. Westman's gender identity wasn't clear, according to The Associated Press.
Easton Mayor Megan Cook said in a statement this weekend that the graffiti incidents are "especially painful" given the Minneapolis Catholic school shooting.
"It reminds us of the responsibility we all share to ensure our children's safety and well-being," Cook wrote. "We condemn such acts of intimidation, they have no place in our community."
In a statement Sunday, the Delmarva Pride Center condemned the graffiti acts as a "misuse" of the international transgender symbol.
"We are deeply troubled that an LGBTQIA+ symbol was misused in a way that could be construed as hateful," the statement read. "Symbols such as the Transgender Symbol exist to affirm identity, celebrate diversity, and foster belonging — not to spread fear or division.
"This incident occurs at a time when Transgender people continue to face targeted attacks in society. We call on our neighbors, allies, and community members to stand together, to reject hate in all its forms, and to embrace the values of acceptance, compassion, and love."
On Monday, Easton Police Deputy Chief Greg Wright said the agency will increase patrol this week at Sts. Peter and Paul School and other schools in town. He said police "have no reason to believe that there was any attempt or desire to harm anyone."
BOND DECISION
Bridgette Lane, an assistant at the Talbot County public defender's office, argued in court on Monday that King should be granted release based on the low severity of charges, an otherwise clean criminal record and the Detention Center's recommendation.
Lane said King has "expressed remorse" and understands "she can't be acting out in these ways."
King, who is listed as having a Baltimore address, was recently staying in Easton with her mother, Lane said. If released, the expectation was for King to stay with her mother.
Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale said the graffiti incident is concerning due to the context of the Minneapolis shooting last month, as well as the fact that King's mother's house is close to the school.
"Here we have this clear warning sign," Coale said. " ... We don't know if the defendant is capable of carrying out something worse. But the state doesn't want to find out."
Ketterman said both sides made good points, but she hammered home that there are "no conditions of release" that would ensure the safety of the community. The judge said she's concerned about the location of the graffiti and King's documented mental health diagnoses, which include bipolar disorder and PTSD.
"I don't think the court has another choice," Ketterman said after ruling no bond and ordering the defendant complete a mental health evaluation.
Information from The Associated Press contributed to this report. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

story.title: Electrical Fire Closes QA High School for a Day
story.author: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com
story.content:
Electrical fire closes QA high school for a day

 September 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 285
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Fire crews initially dispatched for a fire alarm activation at Queen Anne's County High School discovered a small electrical fire around 7:13 p.m. Sept. 9.Interim Superintendent Matthew Kibler said in a letter to the school community that the fire broke out in a special education room Tuesday evening. The sprinkler system activated, limiting fire damage to the room where it started.
According to the Office of the Maryland State Fire Marshal, the fire originated in a rear first-floor office. The preliminary cause was deemed accidental, the result of "an unspecified electrical event of a power surge protector."
The fire marshal estimated about $30,000 in structure and content damages. No injuries were reported.
A total of 36 firefighters responded, with Goodwill Volunteer Fire Company the primary agency in charge. The fire was brought under control in about 30 minutes, the fire marshal said.
The fire alarm company contacted 911, and the school custodian also discovered the fire after the alarm activation.
Water collected in a back hallway, one special education classroom, an office and a conference room as the sprinkler system ran for about 20 minutes, Kibler said.
Third-party contractors were brought in to evaluate and assist. Normal operations resumed Sept. 11, after the school was closed to students and non-essential personnel Wednesday to allow cleanup and assessment. Other Queen Anne's County Public Schools were not affected.
QACPS expressed gratitude to first responders, the Queen Anne's County Fire Marshal's Office, the Maryland State Deputy Fire Marshal, and its custodial and maintenance staff for their work in returning the building to use.
On its Facebook page, QACPS wrote: "We are thankful that there were no injuries, and our fire suppression system worked appropriately."
Questions should be directed to Principal Lou Sheppard, Kibler said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat. All rights reserved.

story.title: Unknown History: Black History Month Offers Opportunity to Recognize ‘The People’
story.author: Niambi Davis Special to the Star Democrat
story.content:
Unknown history: Black History Month offers opportunity to recognize ‘the people’

 February 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: NIAMBI DAVIS Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 211
 Words 

 Read News Document

 This month, in community centers, libraries, schools and churches like Bethel AME Church in Centreville, when citizens gather to honor the nation's greatest champions for freedom, justice and equal rights, they also honor the people.In 1915, the historian Dr. Carter G. Woodson founded what is now the Association for the Study of African American Life and History. The following year, he began publishing what is now The Journal of African American History, a publication of history, research and book reviews.
In 1926, Woodson founded "Negro History Week" to honor the history, culture and contributions of African Americans. He chose February to coincide with the birthdays of Frederick Douglass and Abraham Lincoln. In 1976, President Gerald Ford extended the observation to a month, now known as Black History Month.
Woodson believed that history was "made by the people, not simply or primarily by great men."
Local writer, Niambi Davis had the opportunity to contribute to the Black History display at Bethel AME. The subjects, Davis said, "are important and more than just the usual Douglass and Tubman stories; they're the unknown local, national and international folks."
The display is open to the congregation and anyone wishing to attend services. Service begins at 11 a.m. Sunday mornings. The church is located on Washington Road in Centreville. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

story.summary: During February 2024 Black History Month, the Association for the Study of African American Life and History partnered with Bethel AME Church in Queen Anne’s County to launch a new display titled “The People.” Writer Niambi Davis curated the exhibit, which spotlights everyday contributions of African Americans rather than famous figures. The project honors historian Carter G. Woodson, the founder of Black History Month, and recalls President Gerald Ford’s 1976 proclamation that recognized the month nationally. Organizers say the display aims to broaden public understanding of African‑American history by focusing on community stories and local heritage.

story.title: Understanding Latinidad: Educator speaks to Chesapeake College students
story.author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
story.content:
Understanding Latinidad: Educator speaks to Chesapeake College students

 October 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 639
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — Dozens of students, faculty and community members gathered at the Wye Mills Humanities Cadby Theatre and enjoyed jamaica (hibiscus) agua fresca, fresh fruit, piles of spicy chips and an encouraging message of embracing their native cultures.In celebration of Hispanic Heritage Month, Chesapeake College's Hispanic/Latino Student Union hosted advocate, educator and teacher Samantha Martinez to speak on what her Latinidad means to her.
Lindsay Velasquez, president of the Hispanic/Latino Student Union, said she was excited to bring Martinez as a speaker and loved the encouragement she shared with students in attendance to feel empowered by their cultural identity.
"I just feel like all of us feel like we can do it, and that little doubt that we had of not being able to do something, like, we can do it," Velasquez said. "And she's an example of anything that is possible if you put your mind to it."
Latinidad is a particular experience that contains the complexities of immigration, race, color, class and language. Martinez said her story stems from an immigration story.
"I'm really proud of that because of (my parents') struggle, and their survival and their grit, I'm able to stand here in front of you today," she said.
Her mother migrated from Mexico and her father from El Salvador. She grew up in Chicago, which she describes as "a city that really appreciated and celebrated what it means to be Latina," though the city was heavily segregated.
After meeting her husband and getting married, she moved to New York and became a teacher in the South Bronx, known as the poorest school district in the country. There, Martinez learned of excellence.
She said she was expected to perform at a level of excellence that she had never been asked to before, and in turn she learned to expect it from the people and students around her.
She said the South Bronx "will forever be a part of my story and my legacy."
After spending her time in the South Bronx, Martinez moved to Talbot County. It was a culture shock, but to her surprise, she found a growing Latino population. Her new home also forced her to affirm and challenge her own identity as a Latina.
Martinez worked for Talbot County Public Schools and then founded Mid-Shore Scholars, a college prep program that serves first-generation college students.
When leading the program, she decided it was time to focus on the marginalized student population. The program was meant to target a population of students who had the potential to go to Ivy Leagues, but she pushed for a different perspective. Martinez said it was important to focus on the students who lacked the resources to get to college.
"It's these students who don't have any help at home, who don't have any representation, whose parents want to give them the best life but didn't go to college here, who don't know the ropes or don't know how to navigate the system," Martinez said.
During the pandemic, she decided to focus on building an institution to better assist marginalized communities and helped create the Polaris Village Academy. Martinez said the academy centers joy, celebrating culture and empowering students and families, making them feel safe and seen.
Martinez ended her presentation with photos of her family visiting their native countries and the importance that focusing on her roots allowed her the opportunity to help those around her to grow.
"My superpower is that I am bicultural, that I have roots in (El Salvador) and in Mexico, and I have roots here, and that I can be both from there and from here, and then it's not 'and/or.' I could bring my whole self," Martinez said. "And I encourage all the students here who are questioning their identity or wondering if they can be authentically themselves when they go to class or when they step into white institutions that yes, you can."

story.title: Talbot County Sheriffs' Office Investigating Another Threat, Threat Not Specific to TCPS
story.author: Maggie Trovato
story.content:
Talbot County Sheriffs' Office investigating another threat, threat not specific to TCPS

 September 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: News 
 
 319
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — After a threatening social media post on Friday was determined to not be a threat to Easton schools, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office is investigating another threat that has been circulating on social media.Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said Monday morning that the threat, which originated on Instagram, is not a specific threat to Talbot County Public Schools, but to the 410 area code. He said the threat is a photo of a "clearly" photoshopped Instagram message that includes the 410 area code.
"We're taking it very seriously, as we do every threat," Gamble said, adding that, through investigation, the Sheriff's Office doesn't think there is "any viable threat to the safety" of TCPS students.
According to a letter from the district addressed to TCPS families, the district is "closely monitoring the situation" and working with local authorities. The letter says that school operations will continue as normal.
Gamble said a criminal investigation by the Sheriff's Office is underway. He said all school resource officers in the district are aware of the threat, and extra deputies are patrolling.
On Friday, TCPS students were put in a modified lockdown following a threatening social media post made that morning. According to the Sheriff's Office, the threat originated outside of the United States and similar threats were made to schools in Easton, Pennsylvania.
Gamble said the Sheriff's officer is aware of jurisdictions in other states that "have had 40 or 50 of these types of threats."
"It's happening all over our country where, for whatever reason, somebody is trying to disrupt school operations and put our kids in fear," he said.
Gamble said that a few years back, the district experienced something similar where about half a dozen non-specific threats were made during the course of the school year. He said he would expect to see more of these threats this year.
"This just seems like the thing to do these days for some reason," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

story.summary: On September 16, 2024, Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble announced his office is investigating a recent threat that does not target Talbot County Public Schools (TCPS). The anonymous tip, received on Monday, described a potential violent act but lacked specific details about location or victims. Sheriff Gamble said deputies are interviewing witnesses, reviewing surveillance footage, and coordinating with state police to assess credibility. No school closures or evacuations have been ordered, and officials emphasize there is no immediate danger to students or staff. The investigation remains active, and the sheriff’s office will update the public if new information emerges.

story.title: Videos of Easton High School Assault Circulate Online
story.author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
story.content:
Videos of Easton High School assault circulate online

 September 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Crime 
 
 406
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Videos showing the Tuesday assault at Easton High School have been circulating online. The incident involved three students and one staff member and ended with a student being transported to a hospital for non-life-threatening injuries.According to a press release released by the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, the assault happened on Tuesday afternoon. The videos paint a picture of the incident, though no further official statement has been released by law enforcement on the assault.
In the videos, a group of students are circling around the three students involved in the assault. Seconds into the video, one student in a black hoodie moves toward a student in a red hoodie and assaults him. The student in red falls to the floor. Immediately following, an additional student in a gray hoodie proceeds to join in the assault.
In the video, a male staff member in a white shirt attempts to protect the student that is being assaulted and physically puts his body on top of the student, seemingly to act as a barrier between the students.
The other two students seemingly continue to assault the student in red and begin to also assault the staff member. Soon after, other staff members intervene and separate the students and defuse the situation. The incident lasted around 30 seconds.
Deputies were able to identify two victims of the assault, one was an Easton High School staff member and the second was a student of the school. No identities have been released, and the incident is currently under investigation.
The assault resulted in one student being transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton via Talbot County Department of Emergency Services to be treated for non-life-threatening injuries, police said.
The two other students in the video were identified and arrested in relation to the assault.
According to a statement from Debbie Gardner, director of communications for Talbot County Public Schools, the event is being evaluated and those involved will face appropriate disciplinary action.
"The safety of our students and staff is always our top priority. We are grateful for our partnership with the Talbot County Sheriff's Office and the presence of School Resource Officers in our schools," the statement said. "Deputy Horseman, along with several other Sheriff's deputies and members of the Easton High staff responded quickly to contain the incident. The students involved will face appropriate disciplinary action, and we are continuously evaluating safety measures to prevent or mitigate incidents of this nature." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a violent assault at a high school, focusing on the incident, police involvement, and safety measures, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

key_people: Debbie Gardner — Director of Communications, Talbot County Public Schools

story.summary: On Sept. 12, 2024, video footage of a physical assault at Easton High School in Talbot County spread across social media. The incident occurred during lunch in the school’s cafeteria, involving two senior students; one was left with bruises and a broken nose. Talbot County Sheriff’s Office launched an investigation, reviewing the footage and interviewing witnesses. Talbot County Public Schools placed the accused student on immediate suspension and activated its crisis response plan. Debbie Gardner, the district’s director of communications, urged parents to refrain from sharing the videos and promised transparency as the inquiry proceeds.
